reviews.review: Beautiful neighborhood for a stroll. We stayed close so we took morning strolls through San Blas and loved how charming it felt. Be ready for stairs. But no one is in a hurry so it's a good place if you want a slower place than the Plaza de Armas area. Only took one star away because we couldn't find anywhere to sit and have a cup of coffee.

Get to know the other Cusco. We walked our way through this neighborhood and was a very nice afternoon to stroll around these small houses and streets in Cusco. Go there to see the other side of Cusco!

San Blas, a network of picturesque alleys. San Blas is one of the oldest neighborhoods in Cusco. Its original inhabitants were the Incas, who wove a network of picturesque alleys full of stairs. Cars can barely move in that landscape, that makes it not advisable to carry suitcases.It is remarkable the small church of San Blas, which contains its own treasure: the pulpit, carved in wood, most beautiful in the world.

The place to wander and buy stuff. If in Cuzco you need to go and see this area (take the road to the left of the main cathedral in Plaza des Armas and head up the hill). There are roads and alleys, shops and courtyards full of alpaca, baby alpaca, art, souvenirs, maps and lots more besides. You can wander around and if you want baby alpaca scarfs or throws, then this is the place to get them - do not wait until you get to Lima, as they have very little and it is more expensive. There are also some great restaurants and bars.

Lovely area of Cusco . I stayed in San Blas and didn't leave. I thought the stone streets and old buildings and beautiful views made the area absolutely charming. I felt safe walking around alone day and night. There were lots of great stores and restaurants. Visiting the markets were fun. I was there on a Sunday when the museums were closed so wasn't able to do that. I visited many of the churches and plazas which were lovely. It was fun just wandering around. I highly recommend staying and spending time here.
Most beautiful part of Cusco. San Blas is the most beautiful region of Cusco! Lot of fun coffee shops and restaurants. Check it out!

Lots of handcraft shops. Around here you will find...lots of handcraft shops hidden in a narrow streets and a hole in a wall.There are local women dress in typical dress and carry baby alpaca waiting to take picture with you at the price of 1 sol

Nice traditional area. Almost at the top of the town an old square lined with small shops and cafes. You get s good view over Cusco from here. There are a lot of locals selling hand made textiles but they aren't pushy and don't really bother you, is is a good area just to stroll around and is the center for pottery
Nice walk with.... .....interesting shops. The San Blas Square had vendors and was fun. We had been told that the architecture was interesting, but we did not find any of that.

Perfect for all. I read a ton of reviews before coming here. A lot said to take a taxi to the top because it was too steep? Ok, it is seriously one block of steepness, not an issue unless you are ninety with a bum knee... We went to Peru with out two toddlers (a story in itself) and they both marched up that hill no problem. Besides the fact that there are shops all along the way up...so plenty of places to rest if you had to. We loved San Blas and next time I would love to spend more time there just drinking at a local cafe. Beautiful for all. So no taxi, or you will miss all the shops and all the fun.

This is a Great place to stay too in Cusco.....but Lots of steps...Lots. Cool neighborhood in Cusco, great restaurants and small inns. Very affordable area, safe and walkable. But Lots of steps. So when you go down to the main part of Cusco, you have a really good walk up coming back. But Cusco is very up and down period, so not so important. I really liked the neighborhood and did some shopping there. Fine quality you just have to look for it. Mostly tourist trinkets, but some really good stuff if you look. A little more of a hippy area, but very nice to visit and I would not miss it.
Hill climb = great view. Seems like the hill weeded out some of the tourists. Great area to explore. Narrow streets, artists and shopping.

Great neighborhood. I stayed in the San Blas area of Cusco while on vacation. It was a cute area and very close to the Plaza de Armas. We never had to take taxis anywhere in Cusco because of the convenient location. There were also a lot of great restaurants in this area (Incanto, Don Tomas, Pachapapa, etc). We were also able to walk to Sacsayhuaman from here (little bit of a hike, but definitely doable). I recommend staying at Orquidea hostel in this area (very cute hostel, clean, wonderful staff, and cheap..it felt more like a bed & breakfast than a hostel). If you're looking for a hotel instead of a hostel, there is a Marriott there too.

The best part of San Blas!. Pachupapa right across the street. There are nice locally produced products in the area. My wife loved Pachu papa, where she was able to have guinea pig. She thoroughly enjoyed it. i have an calzone which was very good, though not excellent. Also, the local beer is actually very good. We had wonderful seats in the courtyard, though those seats will not work if it is raining!

Best square to read a book. Amazing location, doesn't attract a lot of people because it is up on a hill but I loved it. Very calm and serene. Could sit here all day on a bench, reading a book and watching people go by
lovely artisan area of cusco. just wander round at your leisure, look at local craft and do not miss the covered Mercado de San Blas: sit down and take a fruit juice with a gorgeous omelette.
Fun and lively. Nice to wander the streets of art galleries and cafes. It is full of life and colour, and is up on a hill. Be careful in the narrow streets.

Beautiful square in cuzco. One one side is a church and on the other is a line of quaint shops and a chocolate museum. Its a beautiful place to relax during the evening or early morning, because the midday sun is very hot! There's also a beautiful water fountain and at the top of that fountain, you can get a beautiful view of Cusco.

Great views from Cuzco at one of its most beautiful neighborhoods. This is a great place to visit if you want to enjoy the sunset and Cusco at night, there are many restaurants, bars to enjoy. This is also the neighborhood where you can find work from well known artisans from Cuzco. Take your time to go there, be careful with the altitude as you need to walk many stairs up.

Thought would be Artistic....Didn’t meet our expectations. Thought this area would be so cool but was disappointed....a few art shops but to my disappointment, it largely had the same touristy shops as elsewhere with very other shops on the artsy side.
Nice neighbourhood. Away from all the hustle at Plaza De Armas just a short walk past the cathedral, quiet cobblestone streets, no cars and little shops.
Nice "barrio". Nice to stroll around and eat or drink something. It's a little bit above from the plaza de armas, but within walking distance. Quiet neighbourhood, also if staying in a hotel there.
Pretty and lovely views! . A really pretty and quaint area of cusco. Lovely narrow streets to wander around. As you walk higher up you can get beautiful views of Cusco.
bohemian area?. This area is frequented by artists and artisans. Nice shops with local handicrafts and textiles. Jewelry shops also.

If you're in Cusco, stay in San Blas. We were so happy to be in San Blas and not in Cusco! Cusco was overcrowded and overwhelming. San Blas is a tiny neighborhood with small walking streets that wrap around the plaza, lined with delicious restaurants, boutique shops, yoga studios, and cafes. It was the perfect place to be! Don't miss it!!

The other side of Cusco. Maybe it's me, but Cusco city centre seems very polished and cultivated for a Latin American city. If you agree, please don't miss out on this area. You can stroll around nice little twisty roads where you are surrounded by more alternative bars, hostels and shops. Best thing is that people actually live here and you can get a notion of their lives and daily business. It takes a climb, but it's worth it!

Beautiful district with lots of galleries and very narrow streets.. Heard a lot about this Art district in Cusco and so finally went there. Its walking distance from the Main square, Plaza der armas. The narrow and up the slope streets lead to this district. On the way there are lot of street vendors selling handmade bands, chains, lockets etc. The main square of this district has markets and also around this district lots of markets selling the art stuff. The prices might be expensive here than other places. Walked around on the narrow streets and checked some galleries. Its a nice place with charm.

Fun Area to Explore. In Cusco, have a quick look at the Plaza de Armas and then head for San Blas. The small streets are fun to explore with all of their small shops, restaurants and bars. I much, much preferred finding places to eat here and wished I'd had time to explore a little more.

A wonderful part of Cusco. San Blas is an atmospheric and picturesque neighborhood in Cusco with limited traffic, blue doorways and quaint cobble streets. It is a short but steep walk from the Plaza de Armas which you need to bear in mind if you just arrived (higher altitude). It is full of little shops of local crafts, clothing, jewelry, art, and items made from alpaca as well as lots of street sellers.I've visited it a number of times and always love it with its benches by the fountain as well as the beautiful San Blas Church.

Upscale Cusco neighborhood. We visited the San Blas neighborhood several times while in Cusco. You have to climb steep stairs to get to it. This is easier to do after you are used to the altitude a bit. There are shops all along the climb as well as great examples of Inca stone work. We ate at a restaurant called Pacchapappas (not sure of the spelling) - great food - don't miss the brownie dessert - we had to go back twice to have this.

Quaint plaza with shops and vendors. Cute plaza area with the best souvenirs I picked up throughout my Peru trip. Make sure to visit the vendor that makes guinea pig and alpaca figures from alpaca fur! There are many persistent street vendors that will ask you to purchase their goods, so be prepared to only buy items you really want!

We spent 3 Days in San Blas and loved it. Prior to coming to Cusco I searched many different types areas for accommodation. I am very happy to choose this area. Like others have said it is full of little shops of local crafts, Jewellery, art, everything made from alpaca and street sellers as well. There is a lot to see here and well worth paying a 5 sols taxi fare to get up the hill to wander around at your leisure. Great area for food as well with small shops selling English books, Stamps, Bakery, water , snacks. It's all in San Blas for sure.
Quiet place at the hill above Cuzco. This is a nice area of Cuzco, with an interesting church, with benches to relax at a fountain , the Coca Museum and good restaurants.

Nice part of the city. San Blas is one part of the Cusco city. To go there you have to walk a little, because the area is a little higher than the Plaza de Armas, so its not very easy to climb, but has a lot of nice places and cafes, so is a nice place to go if you are in Cusco.

An attractive part of Cusco. Cobbled steep streets, blue doorways and Windows, limited traffic and small shops signify the area that is San Blas. Not very large - probably wander around in an hour but worth the visit.
You just have to see the Baroque Pulpit. Apparently carved out of a single piece of cedar, the pulpit is mind blowing - the carving is so intricate. Not to be missed.
Such a nice neighbourhood!. Do not miss it if you are in Cusco! Nice little streets with shops and cafes. I loved it so much! Must go!

Authentic. Everything available in a short walking distance. From hand-crafted momentous to gorgeous garments to last made of alpaca at the best rate compared to mall. Delicious food at several restaurants all while taking in the local atmosphere. Something for everyone. Enjoyed a week stay and did not tire of things to see!
What a find . So glad we were told to visit this area . We spent a good couple of hours ambling around the pretty streets and wondering into the art shops. Bought some good quality local souvenirs.

Great art section of the historic part of Cusco. Great art section of the historic part of Cusco. Fallen Angle restaurant is in this square. Stop in to look at the décor, but better places to eat in the area.
Arty neighbourhood. I loved this part of Cusco. Lots of arts and crafts shops. I bought more than I should have. This was my favourite part of Cusco.

Nice area with good access to rest of Cuzco . Pretty little square, nice spot with some nice buildings around and good access to elsewhere. Some locals selling wares,but much less in your face than elsewhere in Cuzco.
Must see the church. Excellent Church tour, historic. Great fountain and photo site. Go to the bell and see the view of the city
beautiful square. san blas is a quiet place that's good are not as in the central square of fear that all vendors approach you also many lugarex to have coffee with free wifi.
fun. a good place to have more the feel of the locals hang out, not one where all the tour buses stop!! good if you have extra time in Cuzco

Worth a visit. Splendid old church in a pleasant little square surrounded by a few nice boutique shops. The church inside is ornate and the best bet is to buy a ticket for five of the attractions it works out much, much cheaper no well worth it, I think about 30 solos per ticket as opposed to about 20 for just one church! The church boast a very ornate and intricately carved pulpit where you can spot the heads of anti-Catholic figure heads such as Henry Vlll and Elizabeth l.Well worth a visit!
Nice market to shop. At the top of San Blas, is this great artisanal market. Had an exploring the stores and stalls and discovering amazinf and affordable souvenirs and clothing.

Not what I expected. San Blas is a plaza and a long street with shops. Some shops were interesting. Most not at least to me. I do have to say if you like adventure walk down the street. Narrow sidewalks - very narrow - with car whizzing by. Would I do it again? Once is probably enough.
Nice local market. Just a 10-minute walk from Central Cusco, this is a quieter, quaint version of the bigger markets, with locals sitting around, doing photo shoots, playing music.
tour of cusco. beautiful area of cusco. the church is gold and gorgeous, not allowed to take pictures inside, but worth the price of admission.

Lots to see. Don't miss the church.. We wandered around here a bit as suggested by various guides, which was interesting. We then visited the church in the square, which has a fantastic carved pulpit as well as the usual array of statues and paintings. We were then invited to go up the bell tower, which wasn't mentioned in the guide book. Not for the infirm, but a great view over the city.
Nice area. We stayed in the San Blas area of Cusco and loved it. Lots of hotels, restaurants and shops all within walking distance. Very close to the Plaza de Armas.

Good shopping and nightlife. Nice trendy little shopping area with bars, restaurants and hostels. Well lit at night and a large variety of shops. Open until 2100. Only downside is it is on a hillside that always seems to go up!
San a las Market a Must Do!. This place has such amazing and cheap lunches. Sweet sandwiches or omelettes and all sorts of delicious made to order juices! A must do!

Quaint plaza away from the frenzy of Plaza de Armas. I love this area because it's not as crazy as the main square. Lots of artist studios and galleries line the plaza, along with many people selling their crafts. There are also many places to eat in the area. I'm staying for a month in the San Blas area and look forward to exploring the many streets around the plaza.

Shopping. San Blas is mostly about shopping. You have to walk North from the Plaza de Armas and it is a steep climb but you can rest along the way by looking in all the shops. At the top you can shop personally made items at different booths.

Super Place .Fantastic Views.. Walk Up to San Blas....a serious walk UP !!! many shops and cafés worth visiting. It's the Trendy part of Cusco with rather different choices and energies!! The view at night is fabulous as is the choice of food..especially for vegetarians! Lots of Shamanic shops and things to buy!! Enjoy and don't miss it BUT take your time....it saps the energy going up!
Relaxing place - San Blas. This place has a different feel from the main square, it is a more chilled out place. We had a meal and went for coffee, Very quiet, less sellers. I would come back again!

Cure square up the hill. A small square up the hill from the Plaza de Armas with assorted artisans selling their wares, some of which might actually be a little different from the overwhelming number of souvenir shops in town..
great for shopping and eating. Love this spot! There are great little shops there and nice restaurants including a very nice vegan restaurant.
Pretty Little Spot. It is worth the walk to get here. Lovely little part of the city with an artistic vibe. We enjoyed it very much.
cute neighborhood. cute area of Cusco. Some small shops and restaurants are there. much quieter than the Plaza del Armas area of town.

Lovely neighborhood . This neighborhood of quaint narrow cobblestone streets lined with hotels, shops and restaurants makes for a nice walk.
We also walked through the local San Blas market, would not recommend this. It's about 1/50 the size of the San Pedro market.

AN INTERESTING AREA. The plaza San Blas area is a very interesting part of Cusco. There are many old and interesting buildings in the area. There are also a pleat hora of restaurants for every taste and budget.

Good area to stay. We stayed in San Blas on our visit to Cusco. It is very central, but still quiet at night. Only a short walk to the Plaza de Arms and other popular areas. Ther are plenty of mini markets and restaurants close by. Pick up for tours can be easily arranged to meet at the church on San Blas Plaza.
Nice square and view. It is super nice to walk around San Blas as it is not as busy as the Plaza de Armas, the cathedral is simple but with a nice view from the top.

Busy and quaint with lovely market in the square. Very pretty atmospheric little square in the bohemian district of Cusco, nice to sit and chill for a while, with a lovely little market, quirky shops, cafes and restaurants.
Beautiful part of town. Great area of Cuzco, somewhat annoying are the narrow Streets. Cars don't leave any room left for pedestrians!

It was ok, good for souvenirs.. This was billed as a bohemian location. Didn't really come across as particularly hippish ( is that a word?). It had good souvenirs a nice fountain/waterfall, and a neat plaza but it wasn't anything particularly special.
Cute plaza, narrow streets. Narrow streets with little shops and good restaurants. The plaza is quiet and had a local vibe. Worth the walk up from Plaza de Armas. Lots of lodging options too.
Pretty area, nice stores. Nice to walk around and look at low-end and high-end stores. There are good restaurants too. The square is small and usually has street salespeople.
Lots of Shopping. Narrow streets, lots to observe and snap photos of. Great shopping, prices appeared to be less expensive than in the main tourist area (Plaza de Armas)

I don't get it. Nothing special.. Went there expecting a nice shopping district. Didn't see much noteworthy, there's a little square that isn't much more impressive than any other square in town. Shops were nothing special. I wouldn't bother going out of your way. Check out San Pedro market instead.

Peaceful Plaza. Plaza San Blas was such a quiet and peaceful place. It is a definite stop if you are visiting Cusco for a few days. There is not too much to see here, but if you just want to get away from the city center for a bit and see some great views, then this is the place to go. We went during the day right before our flight and loved it. I heard that if you go during the night it is a totally different experience than the day.
Nice cosy place. Much more cosy than the main square. There is a small market and some people playing music. It is also a nice view on the city.

Nice place to relax. I went to San Blas with my husband and two kids (ages 7 and 5). We had a nice, quiet and relaxing time sitting in San Blas main square and watching the water fountain. There is also a nice and very old church next to the plaza that is worth the visit. During the day time there are also a lot of artesans with nice things to see and buy. San Blas plaza is only a short 3 block walk to the Cuzco main plaza. On your walk to the main plaza there are a lot of local art stores with amazing cuzquenian paintings. The 12 angle stone is also near back. Highly recommend this place.

A Very Famous Tourist Spot and Destination. This neighborhood is one of the more popular destinations due to the myriad activities and services available for the curious tourist. The entire area has narrow cobbled streets, adobe structure and Inca Stone walls, a magical place that offers music, arts, handicrafts, cuisine, jewelry, pottery, carving and various crafts. San Blas is very near the Main Square (about four blocks). You can find a sitting spot and “people watch” or walk around and get entertained by the items mentioned here.

Peaceful, not over crowded.. This was not far from the hotel I was at but it is a smaller plaza and not quite the attraction the Plaza de Armas is. However I did find it was a nice place to sit down and recover from the walk up the hill after the visit to the Plaza the Armas.
Great area . Beautiful area. Not far from central square. Great shopping and restaurants. Just be careful of narrow walkways and uneven steps.
Very artistic view. There are plenty of stairs you have to climb, but it is very nice. It gives you a very nice view of the city.

Loved the markets! Realy enjoyed San Blas! Must do in Cusco!. We visited the plaza of San Blas mainly for the markets and weren’t disappointed! Quite a few unique handmade things here, which I haven’t seen at the other markets. It is not a huge plaza but much more laid back than Plaza de Armas, giving it a really authentic Peruvian feel. You can almost imagine yourself sitting here on a Sunday afternoon, sipping on coca tea while the world goes by! I recommend visiting the Coca museum on the plaza. I can’t remember the entry fee but it was really something very insignificant and it was extremely interesting! We just stumbled upon it and I’m glad we stepped inside. The narrow cobbled lane with beautiful original Inkan stone walls, leading up to to San Blas Plaza is very pretty and lined with various little shops selling interesting things and very cheap souvenirs! This is also where you will find the very famous Inka Man who will pose for a photo with you (for a propina, of course)! Also along the way to San Blas, you will come across quite a few traditional old women with baby llamas or little kids in traditional dress who want you to pose for a photo with them (once again, for a propina!) Careful, the women will shove the llama into our hands and then be very upset if you don’t give her money for the privilege. This is a nice experience to have once or twice but it becomes quite a bit annoying after a while – not so much about having to pay every time as it is only a few cents - but it’s really a nuisance how the old women – often with an unwilling child in tow - practically step in your way and become quite rude if she’s ignored. I guess tourism created this mentality so we can’t really blame them for wanting to make a living. Careful of those steps and cobblestones – through years of use, they’re shiny and slippery as hell! My feet just went out from under me and landed me on my backside on top of my camera ($580 damage!...) It was a hot day and I was wearing thongs – not a good idea! Wear something with grip on the sole if you value your tailbone!The whole San Blas area was very pretty and colorful! Many photo opportunities if that’s your thing! I would allow a whole afternoon for this as rushing through would defeat the object. Really enjoyed the whole experience! Definitely a must do in Cusco!
Nice town. Nice town in Cusco. Very arty, with lots of arts and crafts shops. You could spend all day here browsing.
Small but warm square. A small square with good shops of ceramics and museuns. There is possible to see the fountain and de Museum of Coca. Place to take a break.

Wonderful area to stay and to explore. Our hotel was in San Blas and I was glad we decided to stay here. Even though we loved the central historical area, it's quite lively and not too quiet. San Blas is so pretty with its narrow, cobbled streets and character-laden buildings, which include hotels, restaurants, artist studios, and various shops and businesses. It's quite a hilly area so if you have bad knees or have trouble with the altitude, this can be a tough place to get around in. We had been at altitude for over a week by the time we got to Cusco, and it was always a bit tough walking back to our San Blas hotel at the end of the day. I had to take it slow. It's not far from the central square so it's convenient while being away from the hustle and bustle.

Beware - Shady Practices (Cuidado). I had accidently booked one evening at this hotel on Booking.com when I was planning to spend 2 nights in Cusco - when I went back to booking the hotel had no availability... i immediately requested to cancel the reservation because of the error and the lack of availability for the second night... Booking responded that it was at the hotel's discretion and had not approved. I proceeded to call the hotel to explain the situation and they were as unsympathetic as you could imagine.. there was response was that it did not matter because their hotel policy was their hotel policy. I asked to speak with the manager and they said he was unavailable but would return my call - which never happened.Anyway so I tried to dispute the charge through my credit card and the hotel basically said that i never notified them and sent a no show receipt to the credit card company basically to say that I made the reservation and never showed up.Beware of this hotel - as these are clearly shady practices. You would think that the base of their money is made from tourism that they would have a little bit more tact and a higher level of customer service.
Fresh old area of town. San Blas area is perfect for walks, little shopping or it's lovely hotels; it's just a few steps away from Praza de Armas

Go on Saturday for the Artisan Market. A bit of an uphill walk from Plaza de Armas takes you to this somewhat arty and bohemian quarter of Cusco. On Saturdays, the square next to the San Blas church hosts an artisan market - vendors selling pottery, knits, bags, silver, artwork. A great place to pick up souvenirs.

Much calmer than the plaza de Armas . I have really enjoyed spending time in the plaza San Blas and surrounding area. It is much calmer and smaller than the Plaza de Armas, but still really close to the action.

Just like home. These stone alleys could be anywhere in europe. With ex pats from all over selling you hand made trinkets, offering you yoga classes, or some western style food to look over Cusco at. Good for a free walk in the very least.
Friendly People and Super Fun Time!. I met some really fun loving and great people in San Blas, including the bars and Plaza. It's a steep walk from Cusco city center but worth it.

San "Grass" Blas. Full of hippies ready to sell you "handcraft" tchotchkes. Great place to grab food or stay while you're in Cusco. The area is safe and pretty clean. Watch out for the land mines (dog pooh) located on the sidewalk is everywhere
Cool Area with a Great View. Artists, shops, restaurants and a view from atop the main square. Nice walk up the hill and great picture ops once you are there.
Why bother?. one of many, many plazas in Cuzco. Couple expensive shopping places and a few places to eat. Good place to rest as you trudge up hill to your hotel.

Artist section of Cuzco. We stayed at the Tika Wasi Boutique hotel, 491 Esquina 7 Angelitos. Great views and easy walking to Plaza de Armas, and the many shops and restaurants in the San Blas neighborhood. Fine art to nick nacks are available.

Beautiful. It reminded me a bit of Santorini, Greece. Beautiful white buildings with blue trip on the hillside looking over Cusco. It's a gorgeous walk from Cusco and would make an excellent day trip with Sacsayhuaman and Cristoblanco.
Nice visit. The area is central to many walking sites & good restaurants. Good place to stay while in Cusco. More artsy than elsewhere, museums, Plaza's, etc.

Artistic and relaxed. The cosy and at the same time busy streets of the San Blas area are definitely my favourite area of Cusco. Firstly because it seems to be one of the oldest parts of the city, remains of Inca walls in abundance. Secondly because it is a great place to be if you want to relax, just sit on the square in front of the church, enjoy life, music, the lovely and creative people. Many hidden jewels - just don't be afraid to turn round a corner, through a doorway, just enter. If you are looking for nice souvenirs and handicrafts, again, this is the place to be. Enjoy!

Nice square adjacent to historic church in arts community. Nice square with fountain, surrounded by local craft shops and dealers. Artisans can be found making items on the square. Church charges admission to view interior. . A disappointment.

Delightful walking in a historical village!. San Blas is the old town portion of Cusco. It holds so much character and is just a few blocks from the main plaza. The main square has a delightful area to relax next to an amazing water feature. Sunshine abounds in San Blas and the market is one of the best places to grab a bite to eat especially prepared by the local women.
the best. visiting san blas was incredible, that place was the famous artistic location, here you can find the best musicians, art people.

Definitely a nice area to stay in and explore. We stayed in the San Blas area of Cusco for 5 nights and enjoyed this area very much. Many great restaurants and the area is safe anytime of the day. You can easily walk to pretty much anywhere you need to go and if you cannot, there are taxi's readily available since there are lots of stairs to climb up in this area.

Worth an afternoon's visit . A casual part of town with narrow streets, moderate traffic and lots of choices in restaurants, artisanal goods, art galleries, cafes and great views over the entire city. But be prepared for steep walks up and down uneven streets with very narrow sidewalks (or none at all). Try The Meeting Place for good cafe food, The King of Maps for the map lover in the family, Korma Sutra for good Indian food and Taco Mania for tasty Mexican food.

Marvellous Cusco. I spent one full day in Cusco and another half day, when returned from Machu-PicchuReally I feel Cusco deserves two / threee days. The basilica is a real baroque gem. My Cusco Hotel was Casa San Blas where everything is precious.The San Pedro Market was where all handcrafts are cheaper
lots to see. the san blas sight has many historic Inca artifacts to see. I think it cost 10 sole to go and it is wort doing.. this is close to the square
Pretty. We stopped here to visit a cafe nearby. This area has small stores, art galleries, museums, and vendors. It feels very hippy and hipster-ish. There is a church here to and its beautiful!
Hip neighborhood. We stayed here during our Cusco trip and highly recommend San Blas. They have nice artisan shops, solid restaurants and cool bars. The views are super too.

During our visit to peru - 4d3n inca hike, Sacred city tour, moray, we ventured out on our own to San Blas.. We really enjoyed this area more than Plaza d armas. Fabulous place to eat called Green Point - their daily menu is only 15 soles - includes 4 courses and a drink. Fresh made bread and vegetables.
Shopping. Many store keepers and shops. Great time to just roam around this district. Make sure you negotiate with people, because you'll always get a lower price.

A bohemian place.. It is a small place to go, full of little gourmet restaurants, a nice square with an art and crafts fair. The locals sell nice handmade pictures, wool itens and silver jews. The cafes and beer houses are perfect for a rest during Cusco walk.

Visit with best friend, before and after Inca Trail trek to Machupicchu. San Blas is a lovely part of town. I am so glad we stayed at a hotel there rather than around Plaza les Armas. It is a short walk from Plaza les Armas, but much calmer and quieter.

Visit with best friend, before and after Inca Trail trek to Machupicchu. San Blas is a lovely part of town. I am so glad we stayed at a hotel there rather than around Plaza les Armas. It is a short walk from Plaza les Armas, but much calmer and quieter.

If you are into arts and crafts this is the place to go to. Nowhere on our entire 3-weeks' journey on the Altiplano did we Encounter such a splendid selection of arts and crafts and paintings at such quality and such reasonable prices as in the shops and galleries around Plazoleta de San Blas.
Cute neighborhood and plaza . I enjoyed This area of cusco. There were pushy sales people but you have that everywhere in cusco. We visited the church and enjoyed the bell tower view.
It's a fountain. Really nice little area, but only really worthwhile because it was on the way back to the place we were staying. Worth a walk-through
Historique Center. It' s a charming place in the historic place. You have a good view, and i love the bohem atmosphere.
Handcraft quarter. You most go there and lose yourself in these streets! You will find many little shops that are selling typical handcraft in Cuzco. It's a place to enjoy!

Quaint neighbourhood. Going up the steps to the Mirador in this neighbourhood and walking along the narrow alleys reminds me a bit of Granada, Spain. Similar narrow alleys that cars cannot go thru, with great vistas of the city. The vista point/Mirador provides a good overview of the city - we were there in the day and had a great view - wanted to come back at night to look at the lights, but the thought of climbing those steps again in high altitude dissuaded us ... but I am sure it would be a great view of the city - not sure about the stars though as there could be light pollution from the city... the Mirador has a couple of displays showing how Cusco was constructed along the lines of a puma.Walking down from the Mirador, one reaches the San Blas Plaza, where the local artisans come and sell their goods - pretty good quality and at reasonable prices (after bargaining of course). The San Blas church is here, entry ticket needed, but same ticket gets you to the main Cathedral. The San Blas church has an elaborate hand crafted pulpit - their claim to fame, and some paintings, etc.The churches in Cusco when compared against the grand churches in Europe pale in comparison but perhaps it is in this stark difference, and in the absorption of local beliefs/traditions into the Catholic imageries & decorations that makes a visit to one of these churches interesting. There are restaurants and shops around the plaza, Pachapapa being one of them where we had a good dinner one evening.
Quiet, neat, good food. Great, quiet little neighbourhood with some interesting restaurants that was out of the way from the main tourist centre.
Walking the steps up to San Blas was rewarding.. You will definitely feel the effects of the high elevation while walking up the steps, but San Blas is just too pretty and quaint to miss.
nice part of cuzco. this is a cool little are with lots of shops, restaurants and bars. well worth an afternoon walk about. Green Point vegan is close by and this was spectacular.

Little Square with a Fountain and Some Stands . We stumbled upon this square while trying to find a tour company. It's a small square with locals and tourists. There are some stands selling souvenirs in the center. Great place to take a break and people watch!

Great little church. I recommend getting the four church tour pass. I listened to the audio tour, which was great. This audio tour was ily about 15 min but was very interesting. The walk up to the church was beautiful also.
Tiny. It's a tiny square with a fountain. You can meet plenty of hipsters there trying to sell their stuff . There are loads of coffee shops and restaurants.
Cute plaza. This plaza is not as big as plaza de armas, but still has its own beauty. There are few restaurants near the place, as well as souveniors stores.

Nice mood. Very peaceful place. This place is located behind plaza de armas. But not very far away. Still you can reach there by foot. Anyway, fountain is beautiful, and you can check out some museums around it and restaurants too.

Overlook above San Blas. If you are in the San Blas area you may want to find one of the streets that continue to rise out of that area as there is a very nice park that overlooks Cuzco there that has several signs that highlights what you can see from there like the churches, monasteries, etc. it really is a lovely view and informational. When we found it the locals were just enjoying the park space there (maybe more free of tourists than other parks/areas?
Unique and beautiful. Very Unique wooden decorations and beautiful paintings. Ask a taxi driver to drop you at the church first and from there it will be an easy stroll down to Plaza del Armas.

Excellent Artisan quarter. Headed to San Blas church as had bought a ticket to visit the cathedral, archbishop museum and a couple more churches. Learnt a lot about cuscan art which I found fascinating as I am studying a theology degree. It is amazing how Peruvian spirituality has been incorporated into Catholicism. Good views of Cusco from the church tower.Walk up from plaza de armas is steep and narrow with lots of interesting artisan shops. Learnt that stepping inside the shops was a great way to recover your breath. There is also more art and craft at the plaza where the church is with a beautiful fountain. Definitely worth visiting.
Fun Evening in San Blas. We had an excellent dinner at Pachapappas, did a little shopping, and enjoyed the plaza and fountains after dark. It's an easy 4 block stroll up from Plaza de Armas.

Great Shopping!. You can find really good textiles and ceramics here. The prices are higher than in the market, but so it the quality. It is also a pretty place to visit. There is also a museum you can visit if you have time.

Lots of activity on the weekend.. There are vendors set up on the weekends--always quite interesting. A great place to eat up at San Blas is The Meeting Place. They have the best waffles!! The water fountain at San Blas is pretty at night if they have the lights on. Have never been inside the church.

Lovely little place good shops. This little beauty has a fountain waterfall and lots of lovely local shops.
Perfect for art work or grabbing a drink or even some souvenirs!
The coca museum is here too and worth a look for the giggle!
Nice little sun trap here. Very enjoyable

Our favorite in Cusco. Full of retail featuring local artists and home to an outstanding museum of Inca artifacts, this was our favorite area while visiting Cusco. If you are looking for textiles and ceramics a level up from those found in the markets, San Blas should be on your list. A great area for your "home base" if spending a few days in Cusco.
Artist's meeting place. Full of little artists stores, handcrafts, recommended for interested tourists. We were lloking for paintings and wood frames, they were very nice.

Nice square. The square is adjacent to the San Blas Church, on the higher section of the same name neighborhood located on the hill behind Cusco's Cathedral. There is a large fountain, a day handcrafts market and many shops and restaurants.

A nice neighborhood behind the Cathedral of Cusco. This old neighborhood is accessible from steeped cobbled stone streets ob both sides of the Cathedral of Cusco. It is famous for the large number of artists and artisans that live there and the many small shop where you can buy paintings in the unique Cusco style, plus a variety of handcrafts. There are also some large and most luxurious hotels, as well as dozens of smaller simpler ones and hostels, plus many informal restaurants. The neighborhood is on a hillside, only a few hundred meters from the main square of Cusco. The San Blas Church at the top is worth visiting also.

Definitely worth seeing. It's a steep hike from the Plaza de Armas (main plaza), but a must see as this is really very typical of Cusco. Surrounded by old houses and the the Iglesias San Blas, it is almost traffic free which is also nice.

Nice area to use as a base in Cusco. We were really happy we chose to base ourselves on Tandapata in the San Blas area - this square and the locals produce market were highlights but it's also a great location for exploring the historical center and the sites on the hills above town.

Great base for exploring Cusco. When we were looking at AirBnB places for our Cusco stay, we only looked in San Blas and loved using it as our base. We could walk down to the historical center, explore San Blas including the nice locals' produce market, and walk up to Sacsayhuaman and Cristo Blanco. Recommended!

Fun neighborhood. Great area to walk around in. Lots of shops and little restaurants. The streets are very narrow and cobblestone so wear comfortable shoes. The buildings have inca foundations and you can see the original walls. Great place to take pictures.

A quiet neighborhood in the hectic city. We stayed at the Casa Andina San Blas while there and enjoyed the neighborhood. It's such a laid back part of Cusco and definitely worth a visit. It's set on a hill and offers amazing views of Plaza de Armas.

Lovely neighborhood in Cusco. Definitely worth a morning or an afternoon just wandering around. The church is spectacular. Lots of shops and a handful of places to grab a bite if you get hungry. Don't miss it when you arsenic Cusco - it's an easy walk from the Plaza de Armas and well worth whiling away part of a day there.

Pretty nice with a market and church. A short but inclined walk from the Plaza de Armas this plaza has a small market with of handicrafts and souvenirs. Walking around it is a pleasure for photographers as there are many small steep streets and beautiful old corners. There is also a very simple and quaint church worth visiting after seeing the extravaganza of the churches in the center of town. You can also climb to the bell tower for a great view of Cusco.There are various restaurants around the area.
Great area to explore. We enjoyed walking through this area, checking out the local life and the numerous and varied shops. The 12 sided granite rock is within this area as well.
Great little plaza. All uphill, but worth the walk to this quaint little plaza. There is shopping, restaurants, and a beautiful little church.

Chilled side of Cusco. Just a few minutes walk up the hill from the plaza de armas you will find San Blas plaza, where there will be live music, chilled bars, hand crafted goods, good cheap food, lots of veggie/vegan options. Nice spot to get away from the hustle of the main streets

Quaint neighborhood. This is a beautiful quaint neighborhood, with tiny cobblestoned streets and alleys, and even an Inca wall. There are many shops and restaurants. It is uphill to get to the main square!
Small market here in the morning. Small vendors out in the open air here. Nice little square where we picked up small items for the grand kids.
Best neighbourhood in Cusco. this is a nice place to stay, quiet, no traffic, and with plenty of restaurants around, only 10 min walk form Plaza de Armas

Favorite neighborhhod. This is the artsy bohemian section of Cusco. It's situated on the side of a hill and the narrow cobblestoned alleys are a delight to explore. Lots of small shops selling art, textiles and jewelry.

A must. . Staying in cusco for a month in many different locations. San blast is a must. Beautiful coffee, amazing restaurants especially if your a vegetarian. Peaceful and quite and only a 5 min walk to all the bars in the plaza.
Bus up, walk down!. Get a bus to the top and walk down, enjoying the atmosphere of this part of the city. Shops and restaurants to stop at. Go to the local market to see how the Peruvians shop.

Fun Area, Tons of Shops. The San Blas area of Cusco is one of the oldest in the city and is full of a ton of fantastic shops and the beautiful San Blas Church. Also has duds like the Twelve Angle Stone. Worth the time to wander around drink in.

Nice change from Plaza de Armas. We stayed in San Blas and really enjoyed it. There are unique and interesting restaurants on quiet, cute, winding streets. There are lots of artisans and shops but not the hard sell you get around Plaza de Armas. The church is pretty and the entry cost is included in the religious site ticket you can purchase. On the weekends, there is a market in the plaza next to the church. The waterfall in the church plaza is really pretty.

Worth A Look. Our Hotel (Illa Hotel) was 200 feet from the San Blas Plaza and church, and right in the middle of this quaint neighborhood with its narrow cobbled stone streets. San Blas has lots and lots and lots of shops, and, depending on your shopping mood, it can take you.literally over an hours to make the 2-3 block walk down the street to Plaza de Armas. It also has a whole array of restaurants to choose from, We enjoyed our Hotel and this neighborhood immensely.

Cool part of Cusco -- just above town and not so touristy. Also a new view of the hills in the neighborhood. Coca museum now charges but worth the fun tour. Nice places to eat and it's off the beaten path.
good walk.... I enjoyed walking through San Blas during my time in Cusco. Hope to come back again very soon to this beatiful city
Artsy area. It was nice. Very arsty. Neat little streets but nothing that overly "Wow'd" us. Glad we went to check it out but don't think our trip would have been ruined if we had missed it.
Close to the Center: San Blas. Just two blocks from the Plaza de Armas, you will find a neighborhood filled with artisans. Cobbled stone narrow streets give San Blas a delightfulaccent

NICE PLACE. My hotel wasi in sam blas is a veru good places but i litle dnagerous you have to try to bakc early tho hoteland the sundays you can find a tradicional andesn marketthe restaurant arent good but for coffe will be ok
plazoleta. very interesting neighbourhood, hippie, many galleries, coca museum, shops and very good restaurants
San Blas. very interesting neighbourhood, hippie, many galleries, coca museum, shops and very good restaurants
an artist heaven. we loved to visit all the galleries and shoped about a lot of items, we didnt know what to take...its amazing

lares trek at qoriankas style. happy to have met qorianka tours for they arranged me the lares trek....something indescriptible...and after those 5 days, a stroll by the san blas quarter is somethingh good for culturte for its neverending art galleries.

The most beautiful district in Cusco . It is a pittoresque neighborhood with narrow streets, blue white colonial houses and a lot of artists. There are a lot of galleries, interesting shops, cafe and restaurants. I loved this place and I searched for a hotel there in my second visit to Cusco.

Got historical area. Visited the area of San Blas which has one of the oldest churches in Cusco. There is a little market on the square selling local goods and there are a few bars and restaurants around. Good to visit if you like to learn about local culture. There are a few museums there and the walking tour goes there for a visit.

Hostel-y part of town with artisan wares and coffee houses. Well worth a wander around here - there are lots of souvenir stalls but also some great artisan jewellers and ceramic shops. I'm not sure how safe it would be at night to wander alone as it is a little off the beaten track. In the day time it is great - lots of coffee shops with cake and wifi.
Convienient to many hotels. My daughter and I walked around the area. Beautiful architecture, street vendors, and tiendas. There is an ATM (3 together) in a doorway on the corner
A cool neighbourhood. San Blas is definitely the "cool neighbourhood" in Cusco. Full os nice small restaurants and bars it's a good place to end your day in Cusco.

Small plaza, lots of shops, and music bar. I haven't spent much time in this plaza. The time I have spent here was trying to avoid one man trying to sell me art. He was nice but then got mean and I kept refusing to buy. Other than that, the cathedral is beautiful! And it's nice to sit on the bench and listen to the water, surely not as crowded or busy at Plaza de Armes, if you want a small town feel.
Hermoso lugar. Neigborhood amazing. It has beautiful smalls streets and a lot of handicrafts. I love their streets. This place has a quite square with waterfalls bling
Cute area of town. Loved the cobblestone roads of this area - however be careful of traffic on the narrow streets! Lots and lots of tourist shops here and nice views of the city.

Visiting Cusco. After returning from our sacred valley visit, we went at night to this artistic area, is nice to walk around, some of the little streets were derty, but many other streets in Cusco were as well, it looks as part of the culture overthere. If you have time, visit the area, there are many little restaurants and little galleries too.

Sleepy neighborhood. Much of the neighborhood seemed to be closed for business on the weekday afternoon when we visited. There seems to be a backpacker/bohemian vibe, but it was tough to get a feel for the area because the streets were largely deserted and businesses closed.
Interesting area. Hilly area. Interesting neighborhood. Enjoyed the fountain and rested in the courtyard. Passed through in earlier in the morning and there were few people.

Art, crafts and llamas in one block. That is true for a lot of Cusco, but still the artists in San Blas have an interesting conversation. The place is pretty and you can visit, for free, Museo de la Coca.
Picturesque. Very pretty boutique shops on the way, uphill walk to San Blas little tiring. Can walk around the residential area there. Very rustic and artsy decor all around. Worth the visit.
It's chilled out. There isn't much happening here. I basically chilled out in the square. A fee shops exist around the square. And some Street vendors

Atristic Treasures Found Here. This is an art lovers' oasis in Cusco. Friends who had visited Cusco recommended Awana Wasinchis Fair Trade. What a great find. We were told that the color combinations are more subdued, because of the owner's guidance of the craftspeople. Venturing further into the area, we stopped at the pottery workshop of Galeria Arte Olave. The work is exquisitely patterned, but since we were capacity challenged for our luggage, I chose 2 tiny hand painted pots, which will become necklaces.

¡A Fantastic Day Out!. San Blas is a much better environment to walk around and really enjoy, the special exhibitions are generally really interesting, there's a lot to see and if you love art, history and tradition then San Blas is the place to be. Also, there's a lot of climbing up steep paths, with an spectacular view at night. Highly recommend a visit to this area.

some interesting things. We walked through San Blas on our way down from Sacsayhuaman--saves walking up from the main square. We were told that it was the artists neighbourhood, but we found more art type shops as we got closer to the main square. Still, we found some good places near the San Blas church. Right above the fountain there is a little shop called Sacred Silver Joyeria that is run by a nice couple. He is the jeweller, and she does the sales. Worth stopping in. Also, there is a little bakery called Pantastico here--take the time to seek them out. Great banana bread, and everything we tried was delicious. The San Blas Market is much quieter than others like San Pedro, but it was a good place to get fruit juice and sandwiches for really low prices. You can hang out with all the backpackers there. They are happy to share tips about what to get.
A VERY GOOD OPTION. good option if you want to find out the history of artisans find many craft at regular price and good if you want to escape dispatchers flyers in the central square.

A must visit! . Stroll through the tiny streets of San Blas, have a coffee or tea at L'Atelier, and pop in the local bohemian and artisan shops. San Blas is a very pleasant district in Cusco just 10 minutes walking from the central plaza and a great way to escape s little from the bustling tourist activity of the city.

Fun hike up to this neighborhood, but nothing special here to see.. The walk up to San Blas was interesting and great for acclimatization to the altitude. The fountain was pretty, but the church and shops around the plaza weren't all that interesting to us.

Live here!. I lived for one night at Garden of San Blas and I wish I could stay longer. Jesus, the owner, knew everything about Peru and arranged tours for us even when we were hiking the Inca Trail. Love the place and would like to come again!

Charming, a "must" visit when you are in Cusco!. I say a "must to visit" because of altitude sickness I almost missed San Blas. San Blas is clearly one of Cusco's oldest neighborhoods dated around 1563. It's uphill and quite a hike and you'll sure to catch your breath but the sights, sounds, artistic picturesque area will take your breath away.
Not Much To See. There isn't much to see here. It is a nice "tuck in" activity while in Cusco but not a lot to do in San Blas.

Beautiful location, lots of shopping. The walk up the hill to San Blas from our hotel was short and fun. Narrow streets were cool, but be careful! Watch for cars.Tons of fun shopping. Most shop workers are willing to make a deal. Great view of the city. Loved it!
Great area. We had a nice time roaming this area and found great shopping and found where they had and made carnival Masks !We ate at Pachapapa and it was fantastic

Best hang-out spot in Cusco. San Blas is a gorgeous square two blocks away from la Plaza de Armas full of quaint, artisanal stalls and surrounded by cool bars and delicious culinary spots. If you find yourself there of an evening, Taco Mania (just behind the water feature) must not be missed.
Main Square. This is the main square of Cusco our hotel was just few steps close to plazoleta de san blas.. I had great time in Cusco
Good view over Cusco. Went with our tour guide..A little out of the way worth the climb so as to see the view over Cusco.Great to walk the narrow streets and soak up the culture

Wonderful artisian shops. We were able to find those special gifts that were not the usual touristy junk. Many items were custom made by the store owner, others by local craftsmen. Highly recommend a visit to this area.

Be prepared to climb steep roads. It was a surprise for me to find San Blas. But it turned out to be one of the highlights of my visit. There is a lot of climbing up steep paths and at night the view is spectacular.

Hidden secrets. Great place to explore all the little markets hidden behind the walls. Shopping tends to be a more expensive in this part of town so be prepared to bargain or pay that little bit extra just for being there. Home of some of the best restaurants in the city including Map Café, Cicciolinas and El Soleil . Great Museums up this end of town and some interesting artesian shops. Check out some of the boutique hotels and the Marriot for great interior design and a pisco sour.

Artists Quarter. Just a few minutes away from the historic centre. San Blas has a lot of character with narrow cobblestone streets, art galleries and old buildings. We found it to be much less crowded than the more touristy historic centre.

Arduous, but worth it.. San Blas is on a hill above the historical section of Cuzco. It has many fine restaurants and shops. The streets are impossibly narrow and the old Inca steps make you gasp. The views of the city are the best. Although there is a pizza joint on every block you still feel as though you went back in time. San Blas Plaza is always bustling with music and street life. One downside is their propensity for fireworks which are set off with astounding regularity regardless of time of night.

A unique neighbourhood. We stayed in the San Blas district where you get a sense of the history and art in this artisans area. Narrow cobblestone roads, lots of shops and restaurants and many examples of early architecture still exist.

Nice bars and restaurants with some live music. It is a lot of climbing towards the San Blas, but I have had some good meals there and a good night in a bar with live music. The climbing towards San Blas is the only thing that kept me from going there more times. Especially after a day of already walking through the whole city of Cusco.

Better than the Centre of Cusco. San Blas is 5 minutes from the centre of Cusco and better. Lots of different cafes and eateries and some cool little bars and shops. Accommodation seems better value and there are some great yoga studios.

An alternative Cusco. San Blas is a really nice area of Cusco and only a 5 minute walk from Plaza de Armas. It's full of art, hippies and good food so definitely make your way up the steep steps to get to it. Great views over Cusco too, especially pretty at night.

Nice but Overrated. The church is definitely worth spending time. Tons of history. The plaza is pretty dirty and small and crowded with taxis pretty much all day. There are a couple of nice restaurants around there (Jack's Cafe and Green Point - great vegan spot down the street). A good very traditional weaving shop next to the fountain but the rest of the shops are standard tourist stuff.Would not recommend staying in a hostal anywhere around there. Very noisy at night with a couple of loud night clubs right near the plaza. Lots of people hanging around there that don't make it real comfortable to walk around later in the evening. Watch out for religious holidays around here. Expect exploding fireworks at all hours, continuously night and day. Impossible to sleep anywhere near the plaza when things are in full swing. Such events are common and also accompanied by VERY loud music on stages that play well into the night. People gather in the plaza early on such days and drink warm beer all day into the night. Lots of drunk people hanging around during such events.Good for a swing through to see the church but that is about it.
Traditional. A real Cusco neighbourhood.. Perfect to know the traditional handycraft... all the surroundings has lovely views of the city, and god restaurants also (my favorite Pachapapa)
Okay . Okay place but you need a guide.Reviews are really terrific, though, from many of the falls. Lots of nice little architecture of items to be witnessed.

in this plazoleta we found a lot of worthy places. this is a typical little square full of activity and with a lot of people from 4 corners of the world, we could even see some scot showing off their bagpipes, at moments we thought we were in europe.

this is the bohemian neighbourhood. in this little section of cusco you can find gourmet as backpacker restaurants to refill your belly with the most appetizing and delicious peruvian food youve ever have...i like it for i can find a lot of backpackers and adventurers eager to accompany me on some tours.

we were here eating good. in this place of cusco you can find excellent food, typically peruvian for the varied budgets, from the cheapest to the gourmet finest dining with wine, i liked it so much and advice to visit here.

great section of the city!. We booked 4 nights in Cusco and enjoyed every minute of it! There is so much to see in this wonderful city and a must do is a walk over to San Blas. We stumbled on this interesting section of Cusco while looking for a recommended place to have lunch. Loved the little art galleries, artisan shops and eateries. The plaza is small and quaint and a lovely place to pass the afternoon people watching. You don't want to miss this.
Uninspiring . What to say other than a very small Plaza with some artists with mass produced, poor quality products for sale. Take a walk to it if you must, sit and rest, move on....

Overrated little plaza. As the title states it seems as the reviews for this tiny plaza are getting way out of hand.Usually there were lots of cars parked right beside it and sure the waterfall is pretty and colorful.Worth a visit? If you have absolutely nothing else to do, maybe.. but even then it's a close call.
this is the artist borough of cusco. I realkly liked to pass by this section of the city for I could by some souvenirs from the best cusco artists
Great area to stay!. I stayed around san blan square and I really recommend it! Great cafes, b&b's, shops, restaurants. On saturdays there is a market in the square selling great bags.

Charming quarter in Cusco. The San Blas area is quite charming to walk through with narrow streets or stairways, artisan shops, many restaurants offering fresh local daily menus, the main square with its water fall as well as the San Blas church (oldest church in Cusco). Compared to many other historical and monuments in Cusco, the church looks quite flat from the outside and does not stimulate tourists to go in. Nevertheless the inside is worth the 45 minutes and the 15 soles entrance fee which include an audio guide (for an extra 10 soles we bought a combi pass allowing entrances to three other sites in Cusco). The church has several paintings attributed to the school of Cusco and the main attraction is the intricately carved pulpit made out of one piece of wood.
Amazing view of Cusco. A charming walk through the winding roads of cusco with an amazing view at the top. Lots of friendly locals and cute places to eat on the way.

Adorable neighborhood in Cusco. San Blas is a great little neighborhood within Cusco. Tiny steep streets crammed with shops and restaurants and churches. A great place to wander around. Local artists shops all over.

Tiny little plaza sourrounded by artists. Will take a hike to get to, but the san blas neighborhood is fund and this small plaza may be worth it for good hikers, it is about 200 steps up from the main square in cusco
Beautiful little cobble street area. Lots of nice shops and character neighbourhood... Very nice restaurants and a lovely cathedral. Worth the walk.
Nice neighborhood. We walked around here and to us, the best time to visit is the afternoon. There are a lot of shops and restaurants here to visit. Good place to wander around!!

Cool neighbourhood. It was raining when I wandered up to explore the San Blas neighbourhood but that turned out to be a good strategy for randomly ducking into museums and galleries and shops. Many small markets are tucked away into courtyards and very good deals can be had on textiles and other goods.

Pleasant afternoon and evening. I've been here a few times at different times of the day. It is best to visit the site in the afternoon and stay until evening. Wander the tiny streets, stopping for coffee in cafes, visit the local church and explore the local galleries and street vendors. In the evening the restaurant is open, and often plays live music.

I made a lot of friends here. it was one lonely night when finishing eating out I met a big group of local people, they invited me to a party outside cusco and we decided to go with them, my girlfriend was very happy because she wanted to know the sacred valley, we went into the party, and...surprise, it was a wedding party and we were not dressed up as we should be, well our locals friends helped us to let us in...the people here was so friendly and accepted us to havetheir gringos at their party.
A lovely quarter. This area of Cusco is full of interesting shops and galleries, each having their own specialities. It's a lovely place, very relaxing and welcoming.

A nice, artsy area. This is the artist area of the City and a nice place to stay and visit. It is convenient to the Plaza de Armas, as well as some lovely high-end shops where you can get "real" alpaca goods such as sweaters, socks, gloves, jackets, coats and hats. Plenty of charming coffee shops are in the area as well.

ijd town cusco. We stayed in san blas for two days.very charming part of cusco.up on the hill with stunning views of the city, small shops and restaurants everywhere.very narrow streets due to the fact it was built during the Inca period.(they did not have cars then).All cobblestone roads so wear sturdy shoes.The church was very cool

check out Limbus. There will be market on Friday and Saturday if I remember it right. Market is nice with some pretty jewelries and hand-made things. It's worth to take a look if you are on souvenir shopping. During day, you can see people reading on the benches or local people singing casually by the side. But you have to check out Limbus a few minutes' walk from the plaza. The view is great. Especially at night, the food is divine, drinks too. Last time I were there, there's live music too. Great place!

Quaint and Quiet on a Sunday. The Plazoleta de San Blas was very quiet on the Sunday we visited. It is quaint and there were very few people there. There were a few shops open but we did not need a lot time here. It is probably very different on the other days of the week when everything is open.

Nice neighborhood but you need to clime, but you won't regret it. . Nice are with lots of shops and nice restaurants. The ⛪ church was small but very beautiful, too pictures are not allowed. The souvenir shops here are not cheap. So buy somewhere else. However if you you want to buy beautiful souvenir, buy them here. Stop on you way up for a nice cup of coffee or a Pisco Sour
Great area outside of the city center. Short walk from the center of the city. Great place to go at night as there are many great restaurants and that are close to many hotels/hostels.

Very interesting and charming neighborhood 10 minutes uphill from Plaza de Armas.. Beautiful little area, of narrow streets, charming eateries and lodging of all kinds, interesting shops and the lovely San Blas Plaza. Let yourself get lost wandering the lanes, stop for a coffee at the Meeting Place Café. There is a little market every Friday and Saturday at Plaza de San Blas. Oh and if you go way up the hill, there is a wonderful mirador to overlook the entire city of Cuzco. It really is not that far from there to the White Christ statue.
Very nice neighborhood. San Blas is a neighborhood of Cusco, where you can find narrow and steep streets, full of peruvian history and craft shops.

Very safe area, lots of artsy shops, good restaurants and cafes. San Blas is a safe area, lots of quaint shops and great cafes. Its close to the main portion of town (10 min walk down hill, 15 min up hill) and for a taxi its super close and quick. (I'm a tall, white, Spanish speaking gringo and the most I paid for a taxi around Cusco was 4 soles. Aprox $1.32 USD. The area is very safe, We walked around at all different times of day and night. The negatives: In many areas of San Blas there is a strong sewage smell  Lots of stray dogs (friendly but watch your step for dog poop)
Quaint Quarter. Unfortunately, we walked to San Blas on a Sunday when the the entire city was quiet as everything shuts down. There were a few stores open but, overall, it was very quiet.
great vibe!. Nice district of Cusco to visit. Great shops and restaurants! We really enjoyed the vibe in this part of Cusco!
Lovely place. Lovely San Blas, with it's church, plaza, shops and restaurants. It's a good place to hang around, or just sit and enjoy the view.

Most beautifilul quarter of Cusco. In San Blas you have nice Hotels, small placas, very recommandable restaurants (See my review for Green Point). So a good place to stay and explore Cusco. And the center is just a ten minute walk away

Best Neighborhood to Stay in Cusco. We were staying in this neighborhood. I absolutely loved it! It´s so brautiful and it has a very unique vibe. I recommend just seatting in the plaza and read a book or watch your serrounding or climb the stairs up to the view point (Mirador) on the city. There are many cafes and art galleries. Most restaurants open at 6pm. In my opinion it isn´t worth the $5 to see the Pulpito in the church. And ofcourse, there´s the san blas market where you can have a fresh juice for a bargain or a lunch.. Great vibe!
A cute place to visit. This is a nice small plaza that you should go during your visit to Cusco. You will find small but good restaurants around the area.

Take a guide. This was really interesting and added to our macchu picchu experience. I'm not one much for ancient history but the engineering, ways of living and beliefs I find really interesting and our guide targeted these things rather than rattling out dates etc. Worth a visit.
Great church, don't miss it!. It is small, but very beautiful and located in a great neighborhood. Great pulpit and great paintings!

San Blas has great places to eat and shop. San Blas is a great alternative to the busy Plaza de Armas. They have a ton of great eateries (Taco's, BBQ, Crepes etc.). We also especially like the Saturday artisan market as they have some different and unique items not often seen elsewhere.
Cute but very touristy. Cute area but very touristy. Some lovely rococo frames still being done by hand and there are other,artists as well BUT mostly tourist junk for sale in most shops.

Great!. Cusco is one of those cities that you can get around by taxi a a very reasonable rate. There are lots of restaurants and coffee shops. Take your time and see and meet the people. They are really friendly. Even though the altitude is 11,000 it did not hamper our trip.
Best place in Cusco. Close to everything, if you stay there, it is just 10 minuts to city senter.Very nice , full of life place,good restorants,bars.
Restaurants. A beautifull place, where you can find a great number of good restaurants, but prepare for the hills

Great plaza in Cusco. This is a lovely plaza in Cusco close to the main square.
If you are in town on a Sunday, they have a bunch of people selling food in the square. You can get a great plate of arroz con pollo for only 8 soles!
Awesome. San Blas is a nice place, lots of nice handicrafts and nice buildings. This is the most beautiful quartier in Cusco

Best neighbourhood in Cusco. We stayed in the San Blas area for a week. With its narrow streets and walkways, cosy bars, cafes and restaurants, it is the perfect spot to avoid the craziness of the more touristy areas. Each day there is something going on in the square, stalls, music etc. See separate reviews for the El Grial Hostal, Green Point, Boheme and Yoga Room. All recommended spots in San Blas.

Quirky, Beautiful, Felt like Home. My favourite neighbourhood in Cusco -- find a hotel here and stay here! It has shops, pharmacies, hotels, yoga rooms, healing centers, Green Point delicious restaurant, narrow streets, cobble stone streets, and loads of character!

The Artists' Neighborhood in Cusco. There are several stores that show the different styles of the various families that have been creating for generations. The most important is the House/Museum of the Mendivil Family.

More of the same. One becomes a bit jaded by so many people merchandising similar offerings, and our group found this group of merchants did not offer unique pieces. Climbing the stairs above the piazza afforded a view of Cusco and also of the piazza. Venturing much beyond here appeared to lead to less desirable areas so we headed back down to the center of town.

Not quite as advertised. This neighborhood of narrow streets is tough to navigate with the traffic rushing through as one heads up or down the steep streets. Shops along the streets offer religious objects especially paintings along with the usual tourist offerings. While the area is interesting and a fine workout, I think it has only idiosyncratic offerings.

Quaint and Beautiful!. This was one of the most peaceful places we walked around Cusco as the city center is away and the tranquility there is so great. The plaza is not that impressively amazing, but its how quiet and charming it is that makes it unique and great! We had a blast just chilling there for a few hours!

Quaint and Cute Plaza!. We wondered around the streets of Cusco and stumble upon this cute little plaza. We ended up sitting on one of the benches and just listen to some old man playing the Beatles on his guitar. This was a very cool and unique experience away from all the buzz that Cusco has to offer!
Wonderful area of Cuzco to walk around and explore.. This area is the upscale area of Cuzco. It is a great area to walk the cobblestone streets, visit museums and shop.

Nice peacful plaza !. Small out of the way plaza peaceful place to listen to water do a little shopping - cute shops and museum . Great Restaurant PACHHAPAPA!! brick oven outdoor restaurant , excellent pizzas , traditional drinks , traditional food.

One stop on the Church and Cathedral circut. This is one of the 6 places included in the 30 sol combined ticket. All the places are on a walkable circut and can be done in less than a day. All except the last have audio guides which are confusing at first but you get the hang of it! Each church and the arch bishops museum have fantastic works of art and massive gold alters and chapels. Makes a big impression!

History !. History, history.Great . You can enjoy at the weekend , walk at historic place and enjoy the time ! Not many places around the America have walls and houses with more than 400 years and with perfect conditions.Good restaurations.

Relaxed, welcoming feel just off the main plaza. Slightly less busy than the main tourist areas of downtown Cusco. Numerous yoga, vegan and new age places to visit. Would recommend as a place to relax away from the streams of tourists elsewhere.

Best place to stay. The San Blas area was the best place for us to stay. We felt safe and didn't mind walking uphill to return to our hostel. Loved the small local market in the square and narrow streets.

Fantastic artists. The weekend is the best time to visit the Plaza, that is when the small stands are set up for the local artisans. However any day is great to peruse the shops nearby or the free artisan museums on the perimeter. It's also a great place to just sit and people watch with fewer interruptions that at the Plaza de Armas

Beautiful neighbourhood. I loved walking around this neighbour, and look at the traditional houses. If you are up for a walk, as I did, early in the morning, and climb stairs you can reach places with amazing views of the city. It has lovely shops, cafes and restaurants and it is quieter than the city centre. I would recommend to book an hotel in this area.

Worth a visit!. This lovely arts neighborhood sits hi up a hill overlooking the city. Worth the walk up the hill for a bit of a different experience in architecture, shops, and views. The church itself is worth the trip. Really unexpected beauty and history in this church despite its unassuming exterior and small appearance. We had a guided tour and found it to be very interesting. So much to learn just about the carved wooden side pulpit! The history of how the Spaniards converted the natives is fascinating. I love the small ways in which the natives "rebelled" and included their own rituals into the church.

Quiet plaza with a fountain!. This little plaza is tucked out of the way. The roads leading to it are extremely narrow and at some points you'll be crushed against the wall as cars pass. Once you get here, it's a nice little plaza with locals meeting and hanging out. It has a fountain which lights up at night. Certainly less active than the Plaza de Armas, but still nice as a stopping point.There are a few interesting shops in the immediate area that are worth checking out if you're on a shopping spree.

Great Neighborhood. It was a walk to reach this area but well worth the visit to the Church and square. We visited on a day there was a craft fair and my wife purchased a sweater. The local people were willing to bargain within reason which was very acceptable by us.

Nice ambience. This neighbourhood is full of small art galleries, some are open in the morning, others still open in the evening. The streets are narrow and full of travellers. Many modest restaurant. it requires a slow 2300 feet/700 meters slow climbing from the he town main square (easily reached in 10 minutes or less).
Loved the environment. Definitely worth a visit. Nice environment, shopping mainly, but though it's completely nice, specially at night
Lovely place. Fantastic narrow streets lovely old walls and houses is located closer to the cusco city center Impreso ve woe of the city.
Make the detour to here.. Just a few minutes from the main plaza in Cusco, but with some much nice artisan shops and a very nice city view.

You never get tired of been there!!!. Is an small but beautiful district of Cusco. The place is well know as the district of the artists but it has more things to show us, like the church, the square, the streets and galleries of art.

Charming pedestrian district in Cusco. We stayed here twice and loved all the little passages with shops, hotels and cafes. Lots of craft shops. Very pleasant to walk around...although on a hill. Visit La Hada for an ice cream!

Fun place to browse and negotiate a deal for great local art. A quick walk up one the narrow avenue off the main plaza, San Blas is a great place to find hidden art treasures or a simple trinket to remind you of your trip to Cusco. Vendors are affable and hard negotiators, but always willing to deal. Don't miss this little side trip to Cusco!

Charming square and neighborhood. Our hostal was on Plaza San Blas, so we were in this part of Cusco quite a bit. It is a beautiful square anchored by a church and small open/park area with a nice fountain and is considered the "bohemian" part of town. It is flanked by some nice restaurants, one of which, The Meeting Place, really stood out for its tremendous milkshakes. Further afield in the San Blas neighborhood are many shops with native art and crafts. This part of town is uphill from the Plaza de Armas, so the tourist foot traffic is mostly people staying in the San Blas area hotels and hostals. For those not staying the area, it is work a hike up the Cuesta San Blas. If you go far enough up, you can get some good Cusco views. There is a good walk from the area up to Saksaywayman.The only downsides, for me, were the ubiquitous guys trying to sell art prints and a steady stream of cars along Carmen Bajo and turning left on Cuesta San Blas.
Neighborhood Treasure. While taking pictures of the several streets we found this Treasure. If you have extra time walk through the neighborhood and explore.
