Cute place. Nice place to walk around and see the views from above. Being here makes you think that you are somewhere in Spain rather than in Peru. I wouldn't suggest buying things in this area though. You can find similar stuff down closer to the main square and around San Pedro market for way cheaper. The guide books say it is but better quality in San Blas but I am not so sure...

To walk and walk. A beautiful, narrow street shared with cars and small "llamas", among hundreds of sourvenir shops will lead you to a neighbourhood place at the top of a hill, where there is also the Iglesia de San Blas and the square. Real and authentic artisans have their shops there.
Not much to see -. A little disappointed -- there wasn't much to see here. Small shops that are very typical. The plaza was a pleasant place to sit and relax.

Fun neighbourhood to explore. We love exploring all the galleries and shops in San Blas. It's easy to spend a whole afternoon wandering around, shopping, or window shopping. If you have a bit of extra time in Cusco, spend a laid back afternoon in this neighborhood!
Bohemian Cusco. Easygoing romantic square, with a fountain etc. visit the Meeting Place cafe when you're there. Also a relaxed stop if you walk back down from SasquaHuaman fortress.

Beatiful. Lovely town to walk around and enjoy the beautiful stone walls and cobblestone roads. Very steep hills though, I had to take frequent breaks. We visited the local lithier who played beautiful music on his various instruments, made by him.

Great walk and view. Great Colonial location for walking by yourself and exploring the Colonial homes and local stores, the trek begins from plaza of Cuzco, some up hill we are there, also great views.

Art everywhere. This neighbourhood is recognized for its art. You can find souvenirs and "artesanias". For me the best kinf od art was the paintings. There are tons of small stores and one gallery with amazing paintings from local artists. You can also find people selling their own art on the streets.

San Blas church. One of the greatest works produced during the colonial period in Cusco is the pulpit of the church of San Blas in the artisans' quarter. I've admired this pulpit twice now on different trips. It is said that the pulpit was carved from a single piece of cedar and that the skull in the pulpit is that of the artist, Juan Tomas Tuyro Tupac. It is definitely worth a stop.

Do not miss it!. The "pulpito" carved in wood is the most fantastic piece of wood art I have ever seen. It took the artist (a local) 20 years to complete. The "retablo" is also breathtaking. Ask for the video guide when you enter the church. It provides valuable info in various languages.

A very pleasant neighborhood, a short walk from the center.. This is a wonderful little neighborhor full of interesting little shops and restaurants. It but a short but steep walk up the hill from the center. The day we were there, there was a small art show in the area in front of the church.

San Blas Market. We found this market in the San Blas Square by accident and it was the best one in Cusco. Most of the venders there were selling their own hand made products. Definitely above any other markets we came across in Cusco.

Nice neighborhood . You walk uphill from the centre through a typical narrow street with some shops and you end up at a small square with a souvenir ('artisanal') market. Not super special but ok to do, but take it easy with the stairs. The thin air makes any climbing brutal. At the square we had a drink and waffle at the Meeting Point cafe. Pretty good and free internet.
Artists paradise. Amazing place, love the artisans street and quaint shopping and churches all around. I bought a lovely painting from one of the local artists.

Nice neighorbood. San Blas is a very nice neighborhood. It feels very authentic. There is also a nice handcrafts market on the Plaza (Fridays and Saturdays, I believe) and a nice view of the rest of the city.Consider that this is a relatively long climb, specially if you're not used to the altitude yet.
Nice place. You can get great photos at the top of the stairs. Very beautiful in the evening. To visit at any time.

It's ok. First it is a good walk to get there. Of course you can see the church as well. But I've seen better parks than that one, for example the one in front of the cathedral. But it has a nice fountain and the church has a nice altar. But not worth the 10 soles they charge for I think.

worth the climb. The whole district is a fascinating area for handicrafts. The church is very special, with an altarpiece to rival that in the Holy Family church beside the cathedral. There is also a magnificent pulpit intricately carved out of a single cedar tree - rather macabre is the skull of the woodcarver above the pulpit.

A neighbourhood not to miss. I loved all of the side streets, laneways and small shops that feature such a wide range of crafts, art, and fine goods. This is where the artisans are who do the carving, the gilding, the sculpting and the painting. You can watch them at work in their studies and buy directly from the people who create the items. Prices can be a bit higher but you are getting the top of the line in most shops. There are also lots of street vendors and artisans from the countryside who have very unique goods. It is a rabbit warren and some of the best places are down the narrowest streets. Lots of places for good food and beverages and look for internal courtyards where there is even more and some of the best are on upper floors with great street views. It is a safe area during the day and early evening but as usual look out for scammers. Take a cab to the San Blas church and square and take your time walking down to the main Plaza de Armas.
Great atmosphere. What a fun taxi ride here! Fantastic cobblestone streets so narrow you could almost touch both sides at once. What we imagined an Andean town to be.

A second home. I lived here for two months whilst studying Spanish and it is one of my favourite places in the world now. I felt extremely welcome and comfortable, even when my Spanish was really bad. It is a beautiful city with an incredible history and the locals are wonderful. There is a nice mixture of new and old and I can't wait to return one day.

Up up (and up and UP) and away!. The San Blas neighborhood is home to many MANY stairs, which seem more challenging at the high altitude. However, do accept the challenge to tour a beautiful part of the city with great views. Have a drink at Limbo and overlook the area:)

Beautiful Atmosphere!. Spent a few hours at San Blas during a day tour! It is family friendly so you can take your kids. The Spanish influence architecture throughout the town is beautiful. The views are incredible you can see down to the main square of Cousco. Make sure you have a cup of coca tea to avoid elevation sickness.
Beautiful plaza and great vibe. Really nice place to go and spend time. Some nice cafes around where you can take your book and chill out.

Church disco!. Great atmosphere each night at San Blas. The Peruvians seem big on partying in front of their churches!. Each night there were bands playing and families dancing. Great atmosphere and lots of bars and restaurants. We ate at Pacha Papa - highly recommended.

Decent accommodation for only average value. This hotel is well located near most of the tourist sites in Cusco. The rooms are comfortable and clean and the staff is friendly and speak English. They also are happy to help you organize day trips, transport to and from the airport (although it was very confusing whether this was included in the price for one way, both ways, or just as an additional add on).Cusco can be an expensive tourist trap. This place is no exception. For over $100/night you can probably find better as there is nothing particularly exceptional about this place in my opinion. You will have a dependably decent experience probably.The shower was very dependably good, which is not the case in all of Peru. The rooms were not heated and even with the two space heaters they gave us, it was pretty cold there. The little hot water packs were nice though and helped. The free teas in the lobby and decent breakfast were also nice. They had an issue charging our credit card and our payment ended up not going through after we had already left. They requested our credit card info over email which was not acceptable and we had to return to the hotel to pay in the absence of a better option.
Great Area of Cusco. This is a wonderful plaza area. Close to the main square. Great restaurants. Excellent little shops. Just a perfect area to stay in Cusco.
Fun neighborhood. Quaint, artistic neighborhood close to everything you need and yet safe and welcoming. Our hotel was based here, and we enjoyed the hike back to it after a day out.

Mercado de San Blas for great local meal. The San Blas area is certainly one of the most interesting in Cuzco. Walking around the historic neighborhood you will see a lot. For a very cheap but insanely good lunch I recommend eating at the Mercado de San Blas at the place which I've attached in my picture. The Machu Picchu sandwich along with the juice I had is one of the most satisfying meals I've had in a while. The sandwich is loaded with chicken, tomatoes, eggs, cheese, herbs, and a huge helping of amazing avocado. (the best avocado I've ever had) The sandwich will set you back 5 soles as will the juice. Simply incredible quality for the price. I will return while I'm in Cuzco.
Can get an amazing view of Cusco. Very cute neighborhood....slightly on higher elevation. So be prepared to get winded on the many stairs. But it is worth it to get the amazing view of the city.

Explore - but be prepared for steep hill. A short uphill walk (challenging on your first day at altitude, much easier after being here) takes you to the San Blas area. It's only 3 blocks from the plaza. The area has shops, restaurants, and streets to explore. But it is a steep uphill walk. Worth exploring - especially for the weekly market. But be cautious on selecting a hostel here- the walk is exhausting until you are used to it.

Beautiful churches. Take a ticket once and for all for 3 churches and save time and money. They are worth visiting and close to each other even if you must climb a little for this one. Restaurant pachapapa in front of the church is authentic and good

So many shops and places to expore. I enjoyed walking all over San Blas and went to their Saturday market for some locally created art and jewelry. Its a short walk to Plaza de Armas and on to San Pedro market. Con: You'll need to watch out for poop from all the mangy homeless doggies tearing into the garbage (yuck). Poor things.

Nice and quiet. I lived in San Blas for over a month. It is a very quiet and artistic area. On the street over the fountain there are small coffee shops with internet where you can stay for hours and they make excellent different kind of cake. There is a small plaza where you can take sun while listening local musiciens exercising on there instruments. It is very easy to get a taxi and get to any direction.

Get your hiking shoes on!. Well, my daughter swears by pretty sandals and she was fine but there are lots of stairs. We walked from San Cristobal Church and was able to avoid most of the stairs. The narrow roadways and hills and shops make this a very pretty visit. We visited workshops, galleries and stores. There was a pretty fountain and church at the plaza. A very quaint area.

Great area of Cusco for dining and shopping!. San Blas is the artist enclave in Cusco. A short walk (uphill!) from the main square puts you in the middle of shopping, artists selling their wares and some great restaurants. Worth the venture up the hill!

Old Cusco. I was delighted by the steep narrow streets and alleyways. I found the shops, with their doors standing open, very interesting. The age of the place was very evident in the architecture. Certain times of the day saw a lot of cars and very little space to be out of their way, but most of the time there were only pedestrians. Street dogs, as through all of Peru, wander freely, taking little notice of humans, and are given right of way by drivers.

Meh. My guidebook raved on and on about San Blas being the best part of Cusco. Honestly, I didn't see any particular charm to this area. There are a couple of decent coffee shops and restaurants, it may be worth your time to walk through, but I wouldn't feel terrible if I missed it entirely.
Go to the church and get the audio guide. Amazing church, carvings unique and amazing square to visit. You can buy a mult church ticket as save a bit Lots of artists studios to browse also

Nice church, great hike to get there!. The hike to this church was a bit more interesting for me than the church itself. The church is plain, yet very historical. If you are in the area, it is worth checking out.

Great Shopping in Cuzco. San Blas has the best shopping for Peruvian handmade work that we found in Cuzco. There are a number of restaurants at San Blas, but we ventured down a couple of blocks to Jack's for a more American dining experience. Just a couple of blocks more took us down to the Plaza.

Arts and craft abound. This is a very touristy area with many cafes and restaurants for eating with alley after alley of all the usual trinkets for tourists. Well worth the look but there are cheaper areas to get your souvenir.

Great Neighborhood with good restaurants, cafes and art shops. About 5 to 10 mins from Plaza de Armas is the San Blas neighborhood. It is quieter and at the same time has many restaurants and cafes that were very cool

Nice place to shop. If you don't mind walking high up hill ,you can find very nice shop in good prices too !! But I had done most of my shoping around the sq ...so hope others would shop here . And you can take nice picture too !!

Interesting square and architecture. Interesting square set in the hillside (isnt everyhing?), the church and surrounds are worth a look. There are a lot of street vendors which is good, although some can be pushy - especially the 'struggling artists' selling their mass produced prints. One thing to chase up, there is a small (ie about 20 seats max) restauraunt on the upper left side of the plaza that only opens in the early evening. It is run by one lady who makes pasta to die for!

Cute, quiet area, just up the hill. We stayed in the San Blas area (Tierra Viva San Blas), and just loved it. It's a short walk, few blocks away from the main Plaza de Armas square, and it uphill (good exercise). I love how close it was to the main square, but yet it wasn't in all the activity. The San Blas square is small, not as impressive of Plaza de Armas, but it has some cute shops and restaurants to explore. Being uphill, San Blas has great views from above.
Good area to stay in Cusco. We stayed right off Plaza San Blas and enjoyed the area. It was a bit calmer than the main centro area, even though it was only about a 10 minute walk away.

Beautiful and cute!. Short walk away from the Plaza de Armas (uphill, so not easy) but there is a shopping area that has anything that you might need/want. It's quite cute, and has lots of restaurants if you are looking for a place to sit and eat. There are also many travel agencies and you can talk to them if you are looking for anything.
Good place to stay. Great place to stay in Cusco - away from the noise of the plaza del armas and the best restaurants and yoga studios are in the area

Loved this part of town. I really enjoyed the shops and cafes in San Blas. I took the Free Walking Tour and we ended up in a music shop here. A man showed us popular Peruvian instruments he makes and played some of them for us. This is a great neighborhood!
Nice neighborhood. Nice neighborhood to stroll through or stay in - away from the more touristy area. Lots of shops and restaurants. And hills.
A bohemian area of Cusco overlooking the City. Lots of quaint restaurants and shops in a safe area. Very hilly and steep in parts.An up and coming area .

Great shopping, but you have to negotiate. Be sure to stay away from the tourist stores that give kickbacks to tour guides and go to the independent shops where many owners live and work in the back. They will work with you a bit on price, especially if you buy more than one item, and then you also know the goods are really made there.

Some of the best views. Lots of artisans and restaurants and some of the best views of the city. Take the walking tour of Cuzco with Marcos (meet him at the fountain at Plaza de Armas any day at 12:30) and you will end up at a great restaurant at the foot of San Blas.
Good for walking!. If you are up for a good walk, this is a great place. there are lovely bars and restaurants with a nice view, live music.

Hostal Las Pleides, San Blas Area. Loved this 8-room Hostel. Stayed 2 nights before and after our Salkantay Trek. Staff prepared early Breakfast & Coco Tea. Clean,heated, hot water (usually) and caring service. Recommended*

Artisans? Yes, but not exactly what I'd expected. When I heard of San Blas as the "artists' quarter" - I had something fairly concrete in mind. Painters and sculptors, etc., working in original ways to create original works of art. San Blas (unless we just didn't get to the right parts - and we were in the courtyard/plaza of the church!) is more artisanal than artistic. And the resulting efforts are rather duplicative and repetitious. If you have seen one store's collection, you've likely seen them all. (In my impression, at least.) So apart from the fact that the climb got us easily within reach of the MAP (Museo de Arte Pre-colombino) - and lunch in its courtyard restaurant, I'd say I was disappointed by what I saw in San Blas.
Nice little spot to buy gifts. This was a little plaza with a few shops where people can go to buy souvenirs. The people were all very nice and very polite

Nice little plaza with fountains and shops,. Not far from Plaza de Armas and short walk uphill.
Best to spend some time and to take photos with the fountain's backdrop. There are shops, cafe's and the San Blas Church.

Beautiful area. This little area is Cusco is very beautiful. The narrow cobble streets add to the charm of the area that has its own small plaza with plenty of restaurants and galleries around. You have to climb uphill to get here, but it's about a ten minute walk which is well worth it!!!

Great walk or stay!. Recommend this area for having a wander and even great for staying. Cute little cobbled streets with crafts and street food. We stayed in this area and the accomodation was really good both times.
Encatada boutique hotel. The neighborhood is very bohemian with lots of stairs and hills.With great views of the city and very narrow streets are some are just for pedestrians.

Art Street. San Blas is pretty impressive with the streets filled with glimpses of the best Peruvian art culture can offer. There are artworks, handicrafts and quite a few souvenir shops. The people are warm and friendly and the streets are pretty safe and have a lot to offer. Definitely worth checking out while around the area.

Interesting working neighborhood. We bought the three-church tour pass (started at La Catedral on Plaza de Armas) and ended up wandering around this neighborhood's tiny streets. If you like fiber art, you must see the Museo Laura with famed artist Maximo Laura's work on display.

San Blas neighborhood. This is a beautiful and historic area of Cusco. We stayed in a hotel up the hill. The area is touristy. We walked everywhere even later at night. The area was safe, the people friendly and we had no problems.

Great artsy area!. San Blas is a great artsy area of Cusco with lots of great resturants and shops. There is also a really nice little church and a square to hang out in. It[s a bit of a walk uphill from the main square but well worth it!
bohemian. very nice, very bohemian. The streets are full of sellers with paintings and antiques. Beautifull at night,
Hippie San Blas. It is a lovely area with typical hippie vibes, good coffee places, local markets. Fewer gringos than the Plaza de armas
A walk but worth every step.... A very cute plaza.. a must while in Cuzco.. stay and have a beer one of the little bars .. many vendors in the area.. dont miss it..

Quiet neighborhood with plenty going on. We chose to stay in San Blas rather than near the Plaza de Armas and are glad we did. It is much less crowded and restaurants and shops have better prices. It is fun strolling around, although it is uphill when coming from the main plaza. We found the artwork we were hoping for in a small shop in this neighborhood.

Don't miss this neighbourhood. Whatever you do - don't miss the five minute climb up from the main square to San Blas. It's less touristy and has pretty little squares with nice shops. Bought a lovely silver ring from one in the Plaza San Blas. Great photos of cobbled streets, tiled entrances and old doors. Go early before the crowds. At 10am it was peaceful

Definitely worth the walk. Loved walking this area, exploring the narrow streets. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes because of the cobbled streets and many many steps. Lots of small shops and unique cafes. Gives you a real flavor of Peru
lots of local vendors. Lots of local vendors there selling lots of hand made articles. From paintings of local scenes, hand woven tapestries and a great little coffee shop hidden in a corner.

cool, trendy and very hippy part of town. a short walk uphill from the plaza de armas, this part of town is quite a hippy, colorful and very cozy part of town. You find a lot of yoga places and small shops. Also, there is a small plaza around a church. Very cute and worth the walk.
A great area of Cusco to check out!. The streets are filled with vendors and restaurants, if you need anything, you can get it from the San Blas area!

A Wonderful Walk, with Views and Coffee. Lots of arts and cafe's and incredible views of Cuzco!At night you will find local art exhibits and events, and even some live music. But a few levels above the noise of the city disappears and you are left with sky, the city and the surrounding mountains - just wonderful!

Beautiful but many stairs. Our hostel was in the San Blas area so we really got to experience this place.San Blas is beautiful and has many good restaurants (i.e. pachapapa right across from the church), stores and places to see. The downside is that it has many steps. If you need a rest, it was easy to go into a store and look at things. San Blas by the church also has a market where there are many stores. It is very picturesque. Just be careful of the cars. The streets are narrow and can only fit one car. Sometimes you are sharing the streets with a car and you have to go up against the wall to let it pass.
The nicest place in Cusco city. San Blas is a nice place with charm. You can find handricrafts and of course you can relax with the nice views and streets

Don't Miss San Blas Church. Don't make the mistake of avoiding a bit of a hike up the hill to visit the San Blas Church, the oldest in Spanish Cusco. It is easy to visit just the Cathedral and the Jesuit Church (Iglesia de la Compania) and call it a day with churches, but the little San Blas Church has both history and charm. An excellent audio guide in Spanish or English is included.

Historic and walkable. While visiting our daughter, who lives on Carmen Bajo in San Blas, we roamed up and down the hills of San Blas exploring shops in every nook and cranny, and visiting museums. A beautiful and historic part of town. The steps will leave you winded, especially if you're just off the plane. But the sights won't disappoint.

Not what i used to be. This used to be a nice place, but it keeps on losing its charm. Full of stores, cafes and restaurants. It is no longer what i used to be.Cuzco has nice architecture, but it is loosing its charm. Quite sad.
SHOPPERS DELIGHT. Narrow streets with plenty of local shops to hunt for souvenirs and bargains, dont be afraid to haggle, you can get up to 405 discount if you push enough. Lovely old buildings

San Blas is the BEST. Get away from the touristy main plaza and wander up hill on the cobblestoned streets (wear non heeled shoes) and see this area. San Blas is a great district. A bit dirty maybe with the dog poop etc.. but quite a interesting place. Great street art, nice little shops, wonderful views and really cool streets. Take the time to wander San Blas Bario. Find some really unique things to buy rather than the typical touristy stuff.

Nice little neighborhood. I decided to visit this place as soon as I got to Cusco the alleys around preserve this colonial style and and small church but the area wasnt that clean and the shops around this area offered quite expensive souvenirs, if you have free time you can do it

Almost off the beaten path. Very tranquil spot, yet still tourist-oriented. Nice when you want to get a break from all the tourist-filled streets around the plaza.You will have to climb uphill for a bit.

Fun bohemian, artsy district up the hill from the main plaza. San Blas is quieter than most parts of town and features narrow cobblestone streets in addition to its own smaller plaza with a church and pretty fountain. There are many artists selling their wares along with fun cafes, restaurants and boutique hotels. This is definitely one of the better parts of Cuzco and worth your time if you don't mind walking uphill.

Artisan Centre. San Blas is Cusco's artisan centre and is around the Plaza de San Blas. We took a 10 minute taxi ride from Plaza de Armas to avoid the uphill climb. The square has a beautiful mini waterfall, the old Church of San Blas, very interesting shops and art galleries and local folk selling their wares.

Bohemian experience. This backpackers district is unique and a nice change from the craziness of the major tourist plazas in the center of town. Narrow, windy, cobble stone streets give you a different feel from the bus and auto crazed life elsewhere. Backpackers sell homemade wares in the area too.

Very cool place. We initially had a hotel near the main street in Cuzco. We changed hotels and end up in San Blas....and we couldn't have been happier. Gorgeous narrow cobblestone streets, great views, eclectic restaurants. ...etc. it was an experience in itself. I would very highly recommend staying in this area.
Get lost in San blas. Beautiful place to get lost and walk around, there are plenty of coffee places and small shoot to buy everything from jewelry to clothes. Loved it here.
Casa San Blas. This Bed and Breakfast was wonderful during our stay in Cusco. The entire staff was cordial, considerate, and attentive.
Artsy & Bohemian. It’s worth the walk up the hill to see the church and wander the shops. Good collection of art shops, some religious stores, and local artists. Don’t miss the pulpit in the church.

A tiny gem that packs an art wonder wallop. The Iglesia de San Blas is a beautiful little gem and the main reason for walking up to the plaza but there are many other charming reasons to go. The Iglesia's pulpit of carved wood is an absolute treasure. It is must-see. I was completely wonder-struck. I still am. I wish I had done the audio tour, but honestly the splendor of the alter, paintings and pulpit spoke for themselves. The bookstore on the main square was delightful. The plaza is a relatively peaceful respite from the more aggressive street peddlers of the Place D'Armes although there still are plenty. But the fountain and for us sun-drenched public square were refreshing. Just off the plaza is another must-see: the Museo de Maximo Laura. Just breathtaking textile art.
My favourite area in Cusco. The authentic feeling you get when walking in the streets of San Blas is priceless. I love the small tiendas and the peaceful atmosphere.

Pretty square.. The area is popular with backpackers in which you normally find the artisan side of life. This is no exception, we spent a couple of hours exploring the square and surrounding area. The shops are a great place to pick up colourful and quirky presents for yourself, friends and family.Nice coffee shops the one we chose had great staff and calorific cakes..!!
lost in san blas. little cafe, pedestrian street, color, boutique and laboratories, a very pleasant break very close to plaza de arms
Great Part of Town !!!. Great vegan cafe called Green Point in San Blas.Cool shops, and amazing street hill views... We Love Peru !!!We love Peru !!!

still a pintoresque historic quarter. Not far from the historic center and the Center square of Cusco you walk up to San Blas, where you can find bars, coffeeshops, restaurants, terraces and colonial houses built on Inca walls, and from San Blas with its incredible imagery artisans you have spots like the 7&7 Coffee Shop in Tandapata, from where you overlook the whole historic part of Cusco. It is not destroyed by modernisation and its inhabitants and entrepreneurs are very active to keep San Blas safe and attractive. The only downside is that Cusco municipality has not enough resources to collect the garbage, so some days you will come across piles of garbage destroyed by dogs, as the garbage collectors do not come every day.
The best part of the new Cuzco. Lots of shops, including colonial art and framing. I would stay there next time, at the CuscoSan Blas Tierra Viva hotel.
nice experience great view. its like a nice way to know cusco, beautiful little streets, and unique places to eat, to visit and to buy souveniers, ask for the san blas mirador is really nice ;)

Walk the Inca-carved stone streets. San Blas was uphill from our hotel, so we took a taxi up (5 soles=about $1.65), then walked around the San Blas area. There are lots of shops and a variety of sites nearby: the Pre-Columbian Art Museum, the Cathedral, Jesuit Monastery, the Machu-Picchu/Yale Museum. Just walk and enjoy!

picturesque. located very close to the main square, this colourful and picturesque quartier makes you feel to be in greece. you'll enjoy the crowded square full of old ladies who sell their artcrafts. very recommeneded

take a little hike, it's beautiful. I love this little plaza. You will find people taking a stroll or just sitting on a park bench looking at the fountain. I love the souvenir shop on the corner of the plaza, they had some things I had never seen in town before.

Atmospheric. Great neighborhood with tons of attractions and eating options. Walking around is just a pleasure and getting lost in the streets to find another historical gem is just my kind of traveling.

Beaituful and Peaceful. San Blas is the most expat neighborhood in Cusco. It is composed of many little alleyways and streets in which you can easily get lost. To get to the main plaza you just need to go from the main plaza (right side of the cathedral) and continue forward, passing the 12-angle stone, past Jack's Cafe, and up the hill until you reach the cathedral of San Blas. San Blas plaza is right next to the cathedral. It has a beautiful fountain at the end. 2 blocks away from the plaza is a little market with local greens and food. And there are MANY hotels, restaurants, and cafes all around. On Saturdays, there is an artisan market right on the plaza with pretty affordable and unique works of art from local and international artisans. It's a beautiful side of town that you should definitely visit while in Cusco.

Quirky boho place with loads of little restaurants. small streets with character, loads of tiny intimate restaurants with good menu del dia options, lovely San Blas church, dont forget the boleto de turistico (2 or 110 day options) covers this church and many other interesting sites.

A neat area. We stayed just a block from San Blas square. This area has some lovely museums (artisan, weaving) and lovely, somewhat "higher end" alpaca wool shops. The itself had a little market and when we were there bands played as it was a festival.

hadicraft masters. this quarter is famous in cusco because, here are located all the most important artisants of the cusco, as mendivils, also is very nice the also is very nice his pulpit made in cedar wood

A little jewel hidden from the city centre. San Blas is a very local typical neighbourhood, and although tourism there too had its print, it is less to be felt than in the cusco city centre. here people live, and you can feel a little with them. First week of February the saint is honoured with music and dances!

My favorite spot!. Full of restaurants, little plazas and shops!
We stayed there and loved it!
Climb it up slowly and make sure to stop in the little shops and check some of the great artwork!
Music, drinks and art. San Blas is the ideal place to go for some drinks at night. The music and the ambiance is just amazing.

Very beautiful neighborhood for walking. I loved walking around this neighborhood. It was the best part of Cusco for me with the most personality and with the feel of what the city must have been like years before it became a huge traffic clogged city.

Great area for a stroll. If you are up for a good walk, this is a great place. I stayed in this area for two weeks, and I enjoyed the view of the fireworks over Christmas and New Year from this vista. Lovely area. Great views and lovely places to eat .

Great photogenic area.. What a wonderful area to walk around early in the morning. The narrow streets have so much charm and character. The whole area is clean and in area you come to intersect many of the old Inca trails. This is a great walk around area in Cusco that should not be missed.

Interesting exploring on the narrow Inca streets. We stayed at Tierra Viva in San Blas and enjoyed exploring the streets that travel around the hill of San Blas. Lots of great restaurants and sights to see and the higher you go, the better the view.
Good Picture Opportunity. Small area off the main strip but go here to take some cool picture of the rooftops of the old city of Cusco.

Great area. We stayed in San blas while acclimatizing for our 4 day inca trail hike and the area felt vert safe and freindly. The stairs will give you a preview of what the hike will be like if your doing that ( which I strongley recommend).

Nice area and beautiful observation point. It is worth climbing all the stairs to reach the observation point of San Blas (check with hotel the location on the map). It is breathtaking! you can see the whole town and the mountains around. Morning/afternoon are better times to visit because at noon it is very hot and there is no shadow.
Lovely neighbourhood. San Blas neighbourhood is great for restaurants and shopping. A must when you are searching for a special memento. Very artsy and beautiful.

One of the best churches to visit in Cusco!. The church was small and lovely! The pulpit is amazing! The best part? This was one of the new churches that offered an audio tour. I was able to learn the history of the little church and community without having to deal with tour guide and their schedule/pace. I could listen to the facts and then turn it off and proceed at my own pace. Loved it!

Small interesting church. This church is part of the integral ticket which includes the main cathedral and archbishop's palace. Make sure to ask for an audio guide, it is not actively advertized, but is included with your admission. Quality of recording and information is great, but may be difficult at time to identify the item being discusses. The whole religious circuit is very interesting.
nice locality. we chose to stay in a nice apt in this locality. yes, we have to climb steps to reach our apt but it has a lovely local flavor. the cathedral and the plaza are neat too

So beautiful!. The San Blas District in Cusco is very beautiful. Its a very clean area with cobblestone streets and lots of shops, restaurants and shopping. The people were very friendly and the prices for things were reasonable. We stayed at the Casa San Blas Boutique Hotel. I would highly recommend it.
Artisans' Area. Wander through the San Blas neighborhood and you will find all sorts of art work, handicrafts and such while walking down Inca roads.

Favorite neighborhood. We stayed in San Blas off of Recoleta for three weeks. We also spent some time in Wanchaq, and we both preferred San Blas. San Blas is a Bohemian neighborhood, with artisans surrounding a beautiful small square and very clean market. Cusco streets are noisy because they are flooded with taxi drivers who honk at you to get your attention. However, many of the streets in San Blas are too narrow for cars, and it was nice to have a quiet stroll in the busy city. The neighborhood is north of Plaza de Armas, the main tourist square, and a quick walk to most places you'll want to go as a tourist. My boyfriend and I ate lunch at the San Blas market a few times because it was so cheap, at 4 soles per person (1.33 USD). With it comes a bowl of soup, a plate of food and a glass of juice. There are a dozen places within the market to get food or jugos naturales. They also have fresh produce and meat.

Beautiful. Wonder around small streets and ancient houses. Many foto opportunities. Many different places to visit. Do visit the local market and by delicious tropical fruits. The San Blas church worth the (rather short) visit, and it is included in the Archbishop ticket.
Beautiful area. This is a great area of Cusco. There are many options of stores, restaurants and it is very close to Plaza de Armas.

Pleasant part of town. We stayed in the San Blas neighborhood during our visit to Cusco. It is a quiet part of town, 15 minutes uphill from the plaza. It has a pretty small plaza and some nice streets to walk.

An interesting place near Main Square. It's an area just a few blocks away from Cusco Main Square. You can find several nice place in very old buildings to enjoy Peruvian and international food. The view is just great.
Expensive area. Cool place to visit, but not so cheap to have some food or drinks there. So, if you are in a low budget just walk around but dont stop.
The Audio made the tours. Short, sweet, informative and beautiful. Great hike up to the church as well. Nice view by the bell tower, many vendors surrounding the church for more souvenir shopping.
Artist community, shops and restaurants. We ate at Macha Papa restaurant and walked through some shops. I appreciated the art and originality of all the offerings. This beyond T-shirt shops.

Beautiful neighbourhood. We stayed in this neighbourhood for 10 days and loved it. My husband took Spanish classes for the week in this neighbourhood that were excellent. There is a great market where lots o ladies cool lunch for 6 soles and it is beautiful.

atmospheric and adorable. Definately roam around in this very atmospheric section of Cuzco. Lots of artists and painters, galleries and restaurants dot this steep neighborhood. We loved walking around and going into the various courtyards and shops and taking in the sunset from this area. Very bohemian and has a ton of soul.
Quiet andt ypical. This is a nice area that doesn't get too many visitors and not too much traffic. It was nice to relax on a bench near the church and even have a nap.

Nice slipery stone made streets. This is a nice place to wander around
Full of cafes, artists atelies and other small business
It is a little bit hard to walk on the streets, 'cause they are made of old stones and since the sidewalk is no narrow you sometimes have no other option...

A small but pretty square. This is a charming little square. It is headed by two staircases that form part of a waterfall like water feature.
Lots of little shops front onto the square.
great view. Very nice but you need good legs and physical beacuse you have to walk by steps but the view is great to the city

Quaint and full of colour. Perhaps the nicest area in town and best kept for a nice sunny day..if we were to return this would be where we would eat and stroll.full of artists studios and for good reason.
Nice Bohemien quarter of Cuzco. Nice old houses, small streets, bit bohemien, food acceptable. Only negative : you have to climb a steep hill

A spiritual place. This little church took me by surprise. Compared to the big cathedrals in the Plaza de Armas it does not look like much from the outside, but keep in mind it was the first church built in Cusco and before that, guess what...it was an Inca burial ground. Before that... who knows. I do not identify with any particular religion, but felt that this site is sacred. The cost for the entrance and tour is minimal and they provide you with an nice short audio tour. After visiting this church I felt much more connected to the of the city of Cusco and it's deep history.
Great place in Cusco. I enjoyed the culture, the sights and the great prices. If you want to find some great reataurants in Cusco, San Blas is the place!
Fascinating area. Nice colonial back street area. Lots of nice little eating places and even the odd museum !Felt very safe wandering around during the day.

Worth the walk. We walked up the hill to the top of San Blas and, breathless though we were, we were glad we did. There was one store that had excellent ceramics. There were 4 of us and one of our companions bought two prints, which were lovely, at another shop.
Nice streets to take a walk in. Nice artists' quarter, you can loose youself walking through these streets. Nice shops and small galleries.

Cusco Distilled. This is a lovely spot, a short, but uphill, walk from the center of the city, but well worth the the effort. Charming small square surrounded by colonial era buildings, a magnificent church and at least one memorable restaurant.
Must visit while in Cusco. You must visit San Blas while in Cusco. It just a cute, artsy little part of town where you'll want to wander around, visit shops, stop in a cafe, etc.
Good area to stay and visit. Quite a few shops to browse around, although we couldn't find any jewelry. Lovely little square to watch the world go by.

Beautiful area. San Blas is an area where there are lots of hostels and gringos. Lots of artsy people hang out there. They often have live bands at the clubs there as well as artisans that come with their wears on the weekends, The only problem I have is you have to walk(climb) to most of it. There is a steep incline from Plaza de Armas. The altitude is bad enough, when you do this for the first time you fee as though you are going to burst a lung. Take a taxi as far up as you can and give it a try.

Great Neighborhood with lots of Personality. I love hanging out here with all the crafters - I will come play music with them or just chat when I have a free day in the city. Lots of good food and shopping - you cant go wrong!
quaint with some fun markets. Our hotel was in this area and in exploring around San Blas we found a little market of shops, a fish market and/or produce market, a fountain and some nice restaurants.

Loved this neighborhood!. San Blas is cool unto itself, but the walk from the Plaza de Armas to San Blas is really great as well. You get to see so much. Lots of eating, drinking and shopping to be had - but mostly it's the local artists and their wares that make this area so special.

Beautiful!. San Blas is a small little area of Cusco, full of culture. The people are down to earth and welcoming. There are tons of little cafes, resturants and many great, cheap places for vegetarians to eat. San Blas also offers many free or cheap galleries and places to biew all sorts of art. A must to visit!
Beautiful Neighborhood in Cusco. Although very steep and hilly, the neighborhood is the best place in Cusco to explore. Lots of restaurants and shops.
Artisan Center. this is the centre of the artisan, around the Plaza de San Blas. close to the Main square of cusco, the are shops and art galleries

Artisty neighborhood. This was very close to my hotel (a block away), it is packed with small art galleries but you must go into each one to really get a feel of the artist work each has something unique and differs from the typical art crafts you find in the rest of the local markets. Be warned, to be allowed into the San Blas church you have to either pay or by a collective ticket that allows entrance to a variety of churches in town included Cusco's Cathedral at the main plaza. San Blas church has a pulpit carved out of a single piece of wood that it is worth paying for. Adventure on side streets, I personally found the best local offerings at places that are kind off the main tourist path specially those located on Carmen Alto street.

Worth the huffing and puffing. Walked up and down the main street to/from Plaza de Armas. Lots of souvenir shops and restaurants. The original inca walls with a man dressed up as an Inca King was interesting. Stay at one of the B&B/hotel up on the hill for the great view of Cusco day and night.

Charming neighborhood. This is a charming neighborhood up the hill north of main square Plaza de Armas. There's a small central square lined with little shops and restaurants, further up there are winding cobblestoned streets with more shops, boutique hotels and tiny coffee shops. It's worth wandering around aimlessly taking in the picturesque views from various vantage points. Take it slow if this is your first day at this altitude. We had dinner at Pachapapa in the square, a very nice Peruvian restaurant - order carefully, the portions are large.

Vegan Travelers Paradise. As a vegan enthusiast of the arts, I always seek out the bohemian neighborhoods. I really loved San Blas!! There are so many great veg friendly restaurants, charming streets, and local artisan shops. I spent one whole afternoon just walking around taking pictures of the street scapes. It's a little dark and deserted at night, so be careful ! I wouldn't walk around alone after 11pm or midnight because it's simply not well light and there aren't many people around. Really LOVED dining in this neighborhood. A definite MUST if you're vegetarian, vegan, or health foodie.

Artsy. Located a little north of the plaza is the San Blas district. You'll need your walking shoes and be prepared for some steep roads. There are many small artisan shops to explore ranging from artists to instrument makers. Fun few hours, just more taxiing on the legs and lungs than I imagined.

Great little neighborhood but watch your step!. This is a fun neighborhood to explore. So many little streets and niches. The streets, steps, and walkways are mainly old cobblestones that have been burnished by time and wear. They are super slippery when wet. I love dogs (I'm a vet) and there are lots of them everywhere. Mostly friendly, but be sure to avoid bites! Our guide told us of one traveler who was unable to do their long-scheduled Inca Trail trip due to a bite on the leg the day before departure. And there aren't many places for the dogs to go, so there is poop everywhere. Wear shoes with good traction, beware the poop, and have separate shoes to wear in your hotel room for cleanliness.
Great little neighborhood. My friends and I had a nice time visiting the church and markets in the neighborhood an easy walk up the hill from the Plaza Armas
BEAUTIFUL BUILDINGS AND HILLY STREETS. We stayed in this area and it was quite quaint with narrow streets in the hilly area. It is an easy walk to the main plaza and the great churches of Cusco.

Healing House. Healing House is located in these congested streets. The steps, the hills, the people - all absolutely fascinating. Even the taxi driver had difficulty wending his way through this area! The taxi drive itself is worth the visit! :)

San Blas neighborhood. Make sure to see the church in San Blas Plaza. Also eat at Pacchapapa's. Great food! Try the trout or the roast lamb. Yummy!!!! Also don't miss the fiber artist, Maximo Laura's museum and gallery. His tapestries are amazing. They illustrate Peru's history in vibrant amazing colors and textures.

Love it!. Not only can you find amazing restaurants, but also great galleries to shop!! Had a great experience watching an artesian create those fabulous frames! Extremely friendly people! Great shopping! Please do not forget to visit the church of San Blass, pay a guide to share what they know! One thing I would love to share is that we must learn to respect the places of worship, As tourist we can be so loud and obnoxious! If we are there please stop and listen! Leave your chattering for when you are outside! People are very warm and generous!!! Can't wait to get back!
Touristy place with lots of artwork and merchandise. A good place to buy souvenirs and/or artwork like pictures, statues etc. It is a nice and safe neighbourhood with many good restaurants and shops.

Great up-the-hill neighborhood.. This neighborhood up the hill from the Plaza has some great side street restaurants, shopping, and tiny bars. The place gets going at dusk and ends with the fireworks from Cuzco celebrations.
A must visit area.

Near but easy to miss this place. I understand if you do not walk too much around in Cusco, because of high altitude sickness. However, there are small sections of places in Cusco where innate Peruvian culture still vividly alive. Please make your time to visit here and there. TOTALLY WORTHY!
San Blas is a nice district with shops and restaurants. We stayed in SanBlas and enjoyed our time there, many shops and restaurants to enjoy. Be fit for the steep hills!

San Blas neighborhood. We spent a morning wandering the narrow streets of Cusco's San Blas district. This is the artist area. There were several artist shops that were worth visiting, although not all were open.

San Blas is where it is happening in the historic district.. This is my favorite part of the historic district of Cusco. Don't let the small size of the Plazetos San Blas fool you. While it is lovely with its large water fountain and artsy craft stands and stores, there is so much more to the broader area of San Blas. My favorite hotels are in this area and the place is hopping until 10:00 at night. There are many small wonderful cafés to be found along its many side streets, as well as some very well known, larger restaurants. There are also great bakeries and unique antique shops. Take the time to walk along Carmen Alto, Lucrepata, and even Recoleta. The beauty of San Blas is discovering it's very steep and narrow streets and the fun of peering into the many ancient doorways. Because my hotel is on Cuesta San Blas I have spent a lot of time here and love how active it is with young tourists at night. You can also pass through this area on your way up to Saqsayhuaman if you are on foot. No need for taxis here or anywhere in the historic district! You can reach it all by foot if you have comfortable shoes. And it is all cobblestone, so leave your heels at home!
Great area. This is the best area to stay in Cusco. You can walk everywhere from here yet it is so nice and quiet in your hotel.

A little enclave up in Cusco. This little neighborhood about a 10-minute walk up the road from the Plaza in Cusco is full of small art galleries and little restaurants. A nice, peaceful place to do some meandering.

marvecastel "Amazing". The plaza (Incan and colonial Square), and the Chapel were amazing! The work on stone and wood are excellent. The neighborhood is full of local artists and artisans. For a person that likes history and values art and culture, this is a perfect place to visit.
great neighborhood to get lost in. charming, artsy, funky, beautiful neighborhood to explore while in cusco. great little shops for souveniers and cool restaurants.

Fun Artsy Neighborhood. Pretty neighborhood with beautiful, whitewashed architecture and colorful doors. Craft center of Cusco, with artisans selling their wares. Gorgeous area and fun for buying handmade souvinirs.

Great place to visit and stay in Cusco. Wonderful array of restaurants, shops and excellent places to stay. Its elevation above Cusco ensure wonderful views of Plaza del Armas (be ready for some steep uphill walks though!) and its narrow streets and alleys are just waiting to be explored.
A must do when travelling to the beautiful city of Cusco.

Cute place in Cusco !. This place is full of nice shops and good restaurants. Is charming and unique. You can buy nice souvenirs, paintings and eat good, for instance, Pachapapa restaurant is very good in the area.
superb church. what a great place this church is got a tour from the local guy there he was so proud of the great church and its fantastic history!!!
hipster. cute little markets and spots to check out. there's a market on the weekends where they sell small trinkets.
gorgeous plaza. this area of cusco is full fo all kinds of great places to stay, eat buy great artesania. the fountains are nice to hang out by

not what it was 'cracked up' to be. The plaza was full of older men drinking heavily as well as a really bad band consisting of mostly drunk men. The shops were OK, but many seemed to specialize in gaudy gold trinkets and Catholic pictures and statuary. Not at all the "artsy" community we had heard about.

Artistic Part of Cusco. Good for a 1 to 2 hour walk thru the shoppes and street vendors of San Blas. Walking the narrow streets in the evening is a neat thing to do! If pressed for time in Cusco, this is an area you could omit, as I did not see any "Must see" places or events here.

Authentic neighbourhood. Loved it here - narrow windy streets winding up a hill, lots of artisans, a bohemian type of character. Lots of little shops with a different type of product, and cheaper, than the nearby upmarket Nazarenas shops. Lots of cheaper cafes.

the cheaper part of Cusco. When you are in Cusco you should walk through the narrow streets of San Blas. It has a lot of tinny shops with some Original souvenirs. You can also have pretty cheap and delicious food here. the plaza is pretty and the people are friendly.
Beautiful and Quaint. Great little shops at the plaza with nice merch and cheaper prices than other areas. Don't miss out! Great place to get souvenirs.
Sweet small village. Hidden in San Blas, one will find delicious peruvian fare, with spectacular museum, will feel like you walked into a village hundreds of years ago.

Neat church in neat neighborhood. Great neighborhood with cafes and small restaurants and shops, nice market in the plaza, but buy a ticket and see the church. While the church in general is very nice and worth the trek, it really is all about the pulpit. WOW! Woodcarvers, be very, very jealous of this artisan's talent. They have a book on the pulpit for sale for the art historian/architecture buffs.

Worth walking thru it. The artsy district of the city of Cusco where you walk thru narrow streets, visiting art galleries and checking out the many stores around. It composes part of what cusco is all about, so I'd say definitely make it there and walk thru it, even if it's just for an hour or two.

Artsy area of Cusco. We walked up here our last night. There are art galleries and nicer handicraft stores. It has a neat vibe. Skinny streets. Sidewalks that get down to about a foot wide. Its up a hill a bit, so the views down towards the rest of Cusco are pretty-especially at night all lit up. There is a church up there. We got there just as a craft fair was being taken down for the night. Fun stores to wander in and restaurants. We wish we had ventured up there earlier, so we could have visited twice.

Artsy Hip Cusco. We where walking back into Cusco from our day hike to the ruins above the city which is another adventure. As we came down the beautiful stone streets surrounded by ancient stone walls quarried by the Incas we arrived in a lively area of shops and restaurants where we bought an oil painting from a local artist and made dinner reservations for later that evening at Pachapapa. A beautiful part of Cusco.

Interesting area. you can get some great buys on alpaca blankets and textiles here. You probably don´t need to go further than the plazoleta of San Blas because then it starts getting a bit ´bohemian´. We wanted to eat at Papapacha but the wait was too long and we thought it was over-priced so we ended up at a restaurant in the Plaza Mayor which was better, Chicha. Try it!

Funky little area of Cusco. Worth the hike up the narrow street to see the large water fountain and small church. Lots of nice funky shops in this area which has a nice selection of cool things to purchase. Also, has several good restaurants in the area.

San Blas a must. If you are in Cusco for only one day, be sure to leave a few hours to walk up through the San Blas area. It is much less touristy than Plaza del Armas, with great shops, pastry shops and cafés.

Great walking in narrow streets. Outdoor artisan market on weekends, carved pulpit in the church (on the left wall near the front (from a single tree) is trull;y spectacular if you appreciate woodwork (incredible details, on a massive scale), highly recommend Jack's as the safest food in Cusco.
San Blas Church. Beautiful church specially the altarpiece but falling apart with no maintenance at all everywhere. Peru authorities do something!
Worth a Visit. This is a small "Bohemian" area of Cusco full of small shops of artisania and galleries. It is a great place to wander around, sit in the central square, have a coffee or lunch.

Festival was amazing in town.. Prices very reasonable for alpaca sweaters and other items.
Atmosphere fantastic! Had a festival and they were passing around free sandwiches and drinks and dances being presented in front of the lovely water wall fountain.
Lovely fountain in artesian area. The steep walk up the hill to the church and market area is well worth the walk. Many little galleries to explore as you walk up to the market area.

Artist quarter. Plazoleta de San Blas is at the heart of one of the nicest districts in Cusco. It is a popular area where tour groups stay and there is a young backpacker feel about the place. The square itself has a large fountain at the back and is populated with artists selling their wares. Surrounding the square are a number of galleries and San Blas church which has an ornate carved pulpit. You will also find a museum to the Peruvian artist Hilario Mendivil.

Bohemian Art Quarter. San Blas is one of the nicest districts in Cusco to walk around. It is situated on a hill, just five minutes walk from the Plaza de Armas and is centred on Plazoleta San Blas. This square has a fountain running along the back and is surrounded by art galleries and quaint shops with balconies. Narrow cobbled streets lead down to the main part of Cusco, many built on visible Inca foundations. San Blas Church is one of the oldest in town, it has a lovely carved pulpit. There is also a museum to the Peruvian artist Hilario Mendívil.

Lose yourself for a few hours walking aimlessly thru SB. Most of the time you have in Cusco, SV, and MP will likely be focused on Incan ruins, religious buildings, and specific sites. Do yourself a favor and set a few hours aside to wander thru SB and just up the ambiance and architecture this incredibly interesting neighborhood. The winding, narrow streets remind me of Chinese Hutongs! Also there are domestic dogs everywhere, far too many to ever count once you start climbing into the warren's den of streets further up from the church.There is a church and plaza with an excellent waterfall fountain, and some small shops adjacent to it. If visiting on the right day ( and I am not sure which this is, it was there one day and not the next ) there is a craft market in the plaza. The area around the upper part of the plaza has a real hippy, backpackers feel to it with vendors setting up shop on blankets on the sidewalk and selling handmade crafts and bodywear. I know time is so precious when traveling, but if you can spare a morning to just lose yourself in SB I think you will enjoy it immensely!
Cool area of the city. Not far from the main square. On the way there you can see the 12-sided-stone. San blas is a nice little area.
Charming neighborhood. Lots of great shops and restaurants to explore down many side streets. Some interesting art galleries too.
Lovely hilly neighborhood. Charming, old world, with lots of good places to eat (not the usual tourist traps). Visit and if you can, stay there.
the wall at san blas. great look for the 12 sided stone, there will probably be an inca king standing next to it for photos...
nice neighborhood, great views.. nice neighborhood, great views. nice art and souvenirs. i was with kids and stroker is not the best option, sling would work better
San Blas. Beautiful. It looks down on the city. Has nice shops, restaurants, etc. I liked the feel of it. Very peaceful and less harried than the center of Cusco.
Just a part of Cusco. Lots of shops selling paintings and religious artifacts. Step walk up if you have a problem with the altitude
Lovely uphill area. Climb the stairs/side walk and stroll this lovely barrio. Hailed as the art center of Cusco, it really isn't much of one. The area is picturesque and worth the short climb.

Away from the main crowds.. Good place to find some local crafts without the hordes of people. Good place for lunch right across from church. Some local crafts vendors on street. Quaint area. Good place after walk down from ruins.
Best View of Cusco. Walking pass the hippies selling cheap bracelets you climb steps to be rewarded with a magnificent view of the Cusco. Worth every effort.

cozy. San Blas is very beautiful, a very special neighbor where you can find artisans. The church is very beautiful too, the fountain and the restaurants around it. I would recommend visiting San Blas between 6pm and 9pm, maybe for dinner.

Nice neighborhood...scruffy San Blas plaza. The highlight of San Blas is the narrow street or two that eastward up the hill from Plaza de Armas into this neighborhood with its original Incan walls....San Blas feels moderately "nicer" than other surrounding neighborhoods but the stores appear to sell pretty much the same artisan crafts/hats/blankets, etc to be found all around old Cusco...perhaps there are some specialized gallerys there that we missed but it didn't appear so. Jack's Cafe is supposedly great in San Blas. The small little San Blas plaza at the top of the hill was a dissapointment, however, with the church either closed or requiring admission $$ and the adjoining plaza was weed-strewn and not very pleasant.

Nice environment, good walking. Give a break on just jumping to one attraction to the other in Cusco town and surrounds, and take a couple of hours to promenade at San Blas. Calmly walk around in the streets behind Cusco cathedral and San Blas square. There are countless handcraft shops selling cheap souvenirs (certainly where you'll find the largest variety) to art galleries with beautiful pieces, and a handful of small and nice places to eat scattered in the streets. It is touristic, no doubt; but it is also very much Cusco in itself.

A nice neighborhood. San Blas is located pretty close to the center, it is a nice artisan neighborhood. You can find small restaurants and cafes, as well as souvenir shops. It is a short walk uphill, and all the way to the top you can have a view of the city of Cusco. It is easy to go around and discover different things around there. There is a church in their small square which is very nice.At night there is a also a couple of bars around which host live bands. If you want to get out of the crowded center, San Blas would be my recommendation.
So much to experience. The shops, the cafes, the winding, cobblestone streets and the view at the top of San Blas make this a must-see destination while in Cusco.

Fun Bohemian area to walk through. This is the artist section f Cusco, about 4-6 blocks up from Plaza de Armas. It is a hang-out for bohemian/hippie types, among local residences. We quite enjoyed just walking around and getting lost amid the maze of narrow streets, stumbling onto to a local market, and discovering small shops with interesting things to browse.

A Great Area of Cusco. This charming area is a must visit while in Cusco. A 10 minute walk uphill from the central Plaza de Armas, along Triunto Street which turns into Hatun Rumiyoc, brings you to the heart of San Blas with a nice adobe church, the Iglesia de San Blas. While we visited there was a small religious festival about to happen. The locals were building a large religious display up containing statues of many saints. There were also local artisans showing their wares for sale in the main square of San Blas. The view over Cusco from the top of the church is not to be missed. There are many shops to poke around in. A greast way to spend to an hour or two.

Parish church. You should visit this church if you are in the vicinity, it's not worth a detour. It's nice enough but if you've seen the larger churches at Plaza de Armas you are probably satisfied already. You can walk up in the tower for a view of the surroundings. An endearing touch is the sign asking visitors not to toll the bell (the rope is there for you).

Small, but quiet.... San Blas is a smaller and quieter park that is surrounded by quaint cafes and shops. It is not laden with solicitors who will relentlessly bother you. If you are looking to sit in the park and read or to enjoy some nice little eateries, then this is the place for you.
Great spot to visit.... Distance walking from downtown Cusco, very close to Plaza de Armas...local artists..arts...very pretty

San Blas by evening. We ventured up the long steps to San Blas last night to visit the Indian restaurant Korma Sutra. I didn’t like the restaurant much, but I loved the area, with it’s narrow cobblestone laneways and abundance of cafes and bars (see my pictures).I wouldn’t recommend staying here though, as the climb up the stairs from town would get old very quickly. Because it’s a trendy area the hotels and hostels here tend to charge a premium. The weekend market in San Blas might be worth checking out.

Great place to do some shopping. We walked up the street from the cathedral to the San Blas church. The street is v. narrow and has shops all along it. We learned that we could bargain with the shopowners and find some good prices. Everyone was v. friendly... However, do NOT venture beyond the San Blas church as the area becomes less safe.

Artists area of Cusco. A walk around the area will reveal various types of local art.There are a variety of restaurant hidden amidst the streets and are worth checking out. The famous? 12 sided stone will be found in an Inca wall not far from San Blas area.

Cool cultural neighbourhood. Must see, especially on Sat & Sunday market days.Great architecture. Square with fountain.Street above the fountain is compared to Las Ramblas from Barcelona. Take the stairs up from the fountain, turn left walk a short ways and stop in to the Luther there, very talented man where you can view, play, and purchase traditional instruments (guitar, flute, drums).

San Blas is great!. San Blas is a nice place to walk around, it's great specially because it's on the top of the mountain and it has amazing views of the city! The area is chill, it has some nice restaurants, and great to walk around. If I had to choose a place to stay in Cusco I would not stay here as you need to walk up the stairs a lot and it's heavy duty.... jajaja I would recommend something closer to Plaza de Armas...
Most beautiful part of Cusco. Nice hike up from Plaza de Armas. Charming small galleries. restaurants/ coffee shops ( very touristy though). The most beautiful views on Cusco.
Great neighbourhood. Very safe neighbourhood. Lots of shops, galleries, and restaurants. It is meant to be a very arty community.

Worth a walk around. Up a couple of hills, past all the street vendors and you come to this little square. Nice to walk around but I guess our experience was shortened by a torrential downpour. However it did force us into a small café for a coffee and a beer and made me realise that there are probably quite a few nice little restaurants around this are so if you are looking for something different from the main square walk up to this area. Also plenty of little shops selling local crafts.

The place to be!. This is the most traditional "barrio" of Cuzco. In case you are looking for authenticity and a great cultural experience then make sure you book one of the many hostals in this part of Cuzco. We stayed at the “Pension Alemana” and would always go back there. Enjoy!

Hippie Heaven!. Definitely the bohemian part of town, if you want to get away from the typical tourist stuff for a moment in time. Head up to San Blas Square and enjoy the treasures it has to offer ... especially the vendors above the waterfall.
Great Location. It was a bit of a puff up the stairs to get there, especially when lugging around suitcases, but there's lots on offer - views, cafes, bars, restaurants, accommodation.
A must if you're in Cusco. Really quaint and nice to visit. It was nice to see a different part of Cusco. Great restaurants there!

Cobblestone Streets. Cobblestone streets with breathtaking views. Don't go there the very first day you get to Cuzco. Need to acclimate to the altitiude. Just a few steps in this area will wear you out. Great places to shop and eat.

Old town Cusco. This part of Cusco is amazing. Narrow cobblestone streets, so steep that the sidewalks are stairs. Unfortunately the cars race through here as though these are normal streets. And the sidewalks in places are maybe a foot wide. So there have been a lot of near misses!The shops are quaint and there is a lot to choose from just walking down a street. The vendors are REALLY pushy, though. They don't take no for an answer. Don't buy the paintings from the street vendors! The first guy told us that he had studied in art school for 5 years and was now trying to sell his paintings. 5 minutes later another guy was selling his paintings. The exact same paintings!!! Huh.

Lovely. Very nice but be prepared to pay the locals 1-2soles for a picture. Maybe even more if they have a llama and let you pet it. We avoided this as they are just exploiting perus natural atmosphere.

Great little neighborhood. Definitely worth the trek uphill. I found it less 'touristy' (if that's possible in Cusco) that most of the rest of the town. Really enjoyed the views from the tiny streets.
Gorgeous. Simply charming. It is a trip to get up there, especially when you just off the plane. Don't miss it, it's one of the cutest places i've ever seen!

Great neighbourhood to walk around. Hilly*, picturesque neighbourhood with plenty of shops, cafes/bars/restaurants, museums, hotels and narrow streets. Close to the main square and enroute to Saksaywaman.
*Not the most easy place to walk if one has mobility limitations.
Different side to Cuzco. The more sophisticated side to Cuzco, nice art work stores and more chic restaurants, well worth the walk in the area.

Wonderful Neighborhood. We stayed in San Blas for 8 nights before and after the Inca Trail. It's so cute and each side street has numerous cute/inexpensive shops and amazing restaurants. Even though it's a little up hill (difficult when you are suffering the altitude), it's nice to be above the busy city square. One day I fell ill and the rest of our trekking group went out. I was well enough to walk around alone that afternoon, and I felt completely safe.

Tourist Trap. Apart from the hippy waffle cafe (which was great), and the Church, the rest of the area is a bit twee with stalls selling the same things that can be found elsewhere. Not really worth the drag up the (quite steep) hill.
San Blas. Charming area of Cusco. We had a guided tour of the cathedral which was a highlight. Stumbled upon a German restaurant, Heidi, with a filling prix fixe menu for 15 soles ($5).

San Blas. Very nice area, with easy access to many great restaurants. The narrow cobblestone streets accommodate both pedestrians and motor vehicles, so be aware. Short walk to Plaza de Armas, Cusco and the San Pedro Market, which is a must visit, not only for their fruit smoothies but also for lunch at one of the local food vendors; it is actually quite an experience for about $1.00 US.Area appeared fairly safe; but of course one has to be careful in any part of the world. The locals are the most helpful people that I have encountered thus far.

San Blas rocks!. For the last month, I've been staying in the San Blas area in a small hostel at 114 Tanda Pata with private room, bathroom and use of a kitchen for just 20 soles a night and feel at home in this wonderful community. This is a hippy and artesian area with narrow cobbled streets and an array of bars, cafes, restaurants, shops, galleries etc to explore. I've been here for four weeks already and never tire of exploring the area. The San Blas market is small and there's a fantastic Veggie food stall called Govinda Lily's just by the main entrance where you can eat a delicious 2 course meal for just 6 soles. There are also some fresh juice stalls which are amazing value. The church at San Blas is home to an incredible pulpit carved from a single piece of cedar wood which is a work of art and a must see. I feel very safe here, no matter what time of day or night I'm wandering about. I like to sit in the Plaza facing the water feature and writing my journal. More often than not, local people come and sit next to me and I have the opportunity to practise my Spanish. There's an amazing bakery on Tanda Pata called Pantastico and their chocolate brownies are the best I've ever tasted (on the right as you go up the stairs by the water feature). Their vegetable empanadas are great too. I'm going to find it difficult to leave this area - I feel so at home here.

Very good artist district. It is known by the artistic production, but also by the parties. They told me that being alone at night could be dangerous, and I heard many stories of women been attacked, but was fi9ne for me. Sure we have to be alert, because the locals or the peruvians who are there will also be offering some druggs. I like this place and was thinking in renting an appartment for longer stays.

Well maintained; charming. Narrow streets and sidewalks, tiny shops, and a well maintained central plaza make this a charming area. Lots of great restaurant options, some with a great view from the second story overlooking the plaza (I recommend Limo). There are plenty of tourists around, so expect merchants, taxi drivers, and restaurant servers to offer their services.Be warned, pedestrians do not have the right of way when crossing the street!

Town Square. San Blas is a nice little gathering place--another town square. Shops and vendors surround the perimeter.Watch out for the older folks dressed in original garb with lamas...it's one soles for a photo but after you snap the photo each person will fight you for a sole each...not fun when you were led to believe you already paid them.

be sure not to miss. Be sure to walk the steep street up to San Blas, you will see the original Inka foundations along the way, and it is an interesting section of town to explore for shopping, lots of tourist stuff of course, but other interesting shops mixed in

Beautiful at night!. Nice, artistic district. The fountain at the center is gorgeous at night and a must see. Lots of cute little shops and street vendors, but at night really is the best time to check this area out.

Quaint unique area with lots of hidden gems. We wandered up to this quaint area, the narrow streets, small shops and numerous eateries. Wandered might be a strong term, as we'd only just arrived in Cusco and were trying to acclimatise, getting there involved many steep steps (usually not a problem) but 3,000m higher up it was a struggle.It also has some great views over Cusco. Overall a must do when you visit Cusco!

Naked old lady bathing in water feature. LOL!!! We were there waiting for a taxi, when an lady striped down and took a bath in the falls. There is a great restaurant in the back corner of the plaza that serves great waffles, but none of us can remember the name. Also local merchants selling their goods.

Perfect, charming area to stay in Cusco. Narrow cobblestone, charming streets, views of the hills, charming small squares with charming small churches (and a large density of artisan markets, and small shops). A short walk from the center and to many excellent places to eat.

The up market end of town. Yes this is a entertainers corner, the Arty-music-jewelry- foodie area, views all over Cusco, plenty of reasonable accommodation- if you are unsure of where to stay this is for you-safe and easy walk to the central Square (everything in Cusco).

Laid-back hippie and artistic neighborhood. Looks a world of difference compared to rest of Cusco.Liked pretty much the atmosphere, nice bars and restaurants with amazing food set up in menu's at a relatively low cost.

San Blas Plaza. We stay at the hotel Casa San Blas, the plaza was like a 3 minute walk, very small quiet area ,
there is not much to do except to relax, walk, take pictures, souvenirs, eat, churches
Great street to visit!. We wandered up this quaint, narrow street and really enjoyed it! Lots of shops and great feel. A must when you visit Cusco!

Watch out for the hippies. Yes it is a nice place but it would be even cooler if it weren't for the dirty hippies that linger around stinking up the joint. I have nothing against such people most of them are just having fun traveling from place to place, selling their artisan stuff. Some on the other hand are drunk, high and just begging. One joker asked if he could "borrow" 100 soles. How about five...right across the face! The most concentration of hippies smells like a toilet because, well they pee anywhere and every where. If you go there I wouldn't go to late in the day.
A great area to explore. We all enjoyed wandering the streets/paths/steps that wound through this hillside community with great views of Cusco

Artisan Neighborhood. With shops and small restaurants, this is a lively, interesting neighborhood in Cusco. Stroll the streets, poke into the galleries and boutiques, stop for a pisco sour or meal at one of numerous cafes and restaurants.

Best place to stay while visiting Cuzco. I really enjoyed San Blas. Just the right blend of quiet & quaint, and artsy cafes and tourist shops. Small little streets lined with interesting places. It's built on a steep hill, so you get a workout walking around.The only thing I would change about San Blas is the vehicle traffic. Pedestrians do NOT have the right of way, and the streets are very narrow.

Great neighborhood to explore from. I stayed in two different areas during my stay. The first was in San Blas and the second was near the train station. San Blas was much more beautiful, safe and friendly than the other neighborhoods we walked through. Highly recommended.

Quaint neighborhood in Cusco. San Blas has no real access by car. A leisurely afternoon or morning walking thru these cobble stone narrow streets will be appreciated. There are shops and restaurants. If you have time, I would highly recommend spending a few hours in San Blas and have lunch.

Artsy, steep, lovely, quiet!. The walk from the Plaza de Armas up into San Blas requires a lot of endurance! Narrow stairs all the way up may be a challenge but well worth it.San Blas is so quiet and interesting. Many shops, restaurants, and hostels along the path.
