Streets are narrow and a bit muddy when it rains so mind your wheeled suitcase! Love the quaintness and architecture. The locals are so kind and helpful.GO! What are you waiting for?

Nice neighborhood. It has a nice view to Cuzco. There you can find many cafes and bars with different themes. the streets are narrow but very nice. It is a beautiful place to walk day and night. It is quiet but with a very bohemian life.

Only Visit if You Have Extra Time. I wanted to visit this area because I had heard it was the artists' district. I think my expectations were too high. It had the same cheap, touristy things as other areas. I was looking for art galleries - maybe we just didn't have enough time to explore. i would only recommend visiting if you have extra time - but I would not make this area a priority in Cusco.
Over hyped. Nice markets, great location but in the evenings, it was over run with travellers and drunk 20 year olds. Pricey and upmarket restaurants - should be better than it is.
Interesting little area. Lots of interesting shops in this area, However I discovered that the artisional market had the same stuff for much cheaper. Definitely bargain as much as you can here!
market streets. Charming alleys with local artisans keen to sell their wares. Reminded me of Souqs in Tunisia. Practice saying 'No' before you go and stick to your budget.
beatutiful square. Good restaurant directly across from the church with a nice outdoor patio. Cant recall the name of it, but the food was delicious. The Alpaca steak was the best we had in Cusco.
Go to the Markets. Go to the markets, go tp the juice (jugos) stands, and ask for a jugo de lucuma con leche. Get lots of brown sugar. It is the best thing ever. The fruits are organic, and so fresh.

You must walk up here to get a real sense of Cuzco. It is steep but worth it. We took a lane up and because it's on hill behind Plaza de Armas it would be very hard to get lost. Just windy lanes and a wonderful square with artisan shops and a fab museum dedicated to a famous local dead artist whose name evades me but which isn't in Lonely Planet.Down a bit and you come across the most bijou Plazoleta Nazarenas which boasts 4 five star hotels. Too posh for us unfortunatelyLots of good restuarants around.

neighborhood to stay in. If you don't mind the hike up to reach your hotel every night, I recommend this neighborhood for lodging. Easy access to the main square, great restaurants and nice little plaza at the top of the hill.
Bohemian San Blas. Nice place to have a traitional meal in Restaurante Pachapapa. Only 15 minutes away from the city center in Cusco. You will like the small streets and the ambiance.

Go late as nothing is open in the mornings. The views of the city from the San Blas area are lovely, and worth the hike up the steep steps to get there. However, if you're looking to visit the shops and eateries in this area, go after about 1pm as nothing much is open before then. There are some nice handicrafts for sale from a small open-air market at the top of the fountain in the San Blas Square where there are artisans making their wares, and hair braiding is on offer. Check out The Meeting Place Cafe in the Square for good, cheap, socially responsible food - 100% of profits go to local charities and projects.
Historic neighborhood. A beautiful and historic area in Cusco city that one must walk. It also houses really nice shops with all kinds of handicrafts for sale. Also check for antiques

The Bohemian heart of Cuzco. Artisty, unique, authentic
San Blas is the patron saint of artists and the neighborhood is just that an artistic display of paintings, crafts, jewelry. Must visit.

Great place to purchase art. San Blas was a bit of a hike from the Plaza de Armas but it is worth it. There are lots of shops selling amazing religious paintings, as well as the traditional touristy stuff too. Several good restaurants are located here too.

very touristy. The district is for artists, unfortunately most of the work on display is more touristy than artzy, nevertheless if you spend enought time there you can find some interesting work that elsewhere could be worth something

Good food and shopping. Pachapapa restaurant is here; lots of shops selling Cusquena art.
Church here has one of the most impressive carved wooden pulpits in the Western Hemisphere.

Worth the hike. San Blas isn't undiscovered. But it's better than milling through the throng of people closer to the plaza. If obviousness bothers you, San Blas is a partial cure: the walk up from the plaza may make your head throb (given that you're already at 11,000 feet above sea level), but it's worth the hike to find quality artisan shops, funkier little bars and 4-table restaurant nooks, lesser-known courtyards and a wandering llama or two. In San Blas, the general law of overseas travel applies: The less convenient a place is to get to, the fewer bozo travelers you'll encounter and the more interesting your experience will be.
Worth a tough walk up. Very steep clim up here but it's a nice area. On your first day if you are not acclimatised yet you may find it to tough going to get to it so leave it to the second day

Pretty view. Love to sit here and just read and see how life goes by, but it feels great! What i dont like so much is all the mochileros trying to sell you candies, im old enough to get candy from strangers, but i have no clue how they were done, they never look that good, be aware of it.

Loved it!. I lived in Cusco last year and first lived near the market (on Chaparro Road). I didn't like it at all, and I quickly moved to San Blas. San Blas has this really amazing vibe. It feels rustic and old, but yet retains many lovely restaurants and a square with a church. It's of course full or tourists and people trying to sell things to tourist. So the only annoying thing is that I would walk out my front door and have half a dozen sellers trying to sell me something. But it's just an amazing place and I am sure I will move back there again sometime in the future.

Great Location. We stayed at San Blas while traveling to Machu Picchu. The staff was helpful and stored our packs for a couple of days while we visited Machu Picchu - very helpful.The included breakfast was adequate and on par with what we paid for our accommodation.The room was a good size with comfortable beds. The bathroom was adequate, but like many hotels and hostels, the hot water was sporadic.Because Cusco is in the Andes, the nights are cold, so be prepared to pile on an extra blanket - which was available in our room.The location was great to explore the older areas of Cusco.There was good Wifi but weHad to go to the roof top patio - not a hardship.The restaurant next store was worth a visit too. Very good food reasonably priced. Overall, good value accommodation for the seasoned backpack traveller.
San Blas. Excellent place to live in Cusco! The view on the city is amazing and because of the steepness you will see if you are acclimatized for your trek!

Beautiful area to explore and shop. San Blas is a short walk from the main Plaza de Armas. There are picturesque streets and alleys, and the stairs really aren't too bad. Good restaurants, too. The San Blas Plaza is certainly worth a visit when the artisans are out. Plenty of handmade goods to look at and purchase! The vendors all approach you to buy (like anywhere else in Cusco), but they aren't pushy and respect a "no, gracias." For a good view of the city, keep walking higher in the neighborhood and turn around!

Well worth the climb up!. The hike up the hill to this neighborhood was tough while we were acclimating, but it was well worth the view we were rewarded with! The bohemian neighborhood is filled with art galleries, churches, street vendors and of course Jack's place if you are looking for a traditional (non peruvian) big breakfast and sandwiches! Keep climbing up until you reach the overlook and look out over the city on the tiled roofs and congratulate yourself for the climb up. Your photos will be stunning!

Walking Tour information helps with this area. We enjoyed walking around this area. But I think that it helped that we were following the walking tour information in our book, since it helped us to see areas we may have missed otherwise. It has a nice quaint feel to it when you get away from the clouds.
Great art, shops, plaza, restaurants.. Great Saturday local artisan mercado. Enjoyed a couple of dinners at PacchiPapas. Many music festivals take place in front of the fountain.
Fun Neighborhood. Fun place to walk around and shop, have a drink and eat. They had music playing in the square that we enjoyed.

The artistic area of Cusco. Prepare to do a lot of walking as this area is set on a very steep uphill , but if you make it to the top of the stairs the view of the city is incredible. We stopped at a little café for drinks and a bite to eat. The area looks very old and run-down, but there is nothing wrong with the food!
Nice part of town. I stayed at a hotel in this district. It is very pretty and high up. Has a lovely park and nice bars and restaurants.
Nice neighborhood. Windy streets with a lot of shops. If you've been tramping through the mountains and your wife needs a taste of civilization, take her here to do some shopping.

A beautiful place to stroll. This is a really romantic place. Little streets, little shops, little restaurants. It is a wonderful place to get lost and stroll around. The only one problem is the traffic. Inside this gorgeus streets circulate lots of cars. That's unbelievable. This should be banned to preserve the magic atmosphere of the place.

Interesting wanders, historic areas. Just up from the Plaza de Armas in Cusco is this neighborhood of steep and narrow cobblestone street and stairways with historic stone buildings all around. Many little testile shops art museums/shops, restaurants and hostals/hotels as well as some interesting museums and historical attractions are in the picturesque neighbourhood. Well worth a half day wandering

dangerous!!! dont go at night!!!. if you dont want to get rob or kipnaped by a local taxi and bring to the atm machines to get money..dont go at night !! is very dangerous, lots of drougs and young pic pocket crazy young drogatic kids

very nice public square. we were fortunate to be in Cusco the for Mother's Day weekend. There was a celebration in the square involving native dancers and music. There is a small craft market in the square every Sunday that is very nice.

A Must. This small, quiet Plaza has true Peruvian charm. The small church is quite interesting, and the Plaza is surrounded by really neat shops. Also in the Plaza, you will find Pachapapa Restaurant, one of the best places to eat in Cusco. Don't miss Plaza San Blas!

Visit if you have seen everything else that you want to see. We were disappointed in San Blas. It was not a pretty artsy area as I had hoped. The shops were uninteresting and not well-stocked. I enjoy to some extent every area that I get to see of a city I'm visiting, but we could have used the time a little better visiting somewhere else.
Excelent place for shopping. you have to go if you want to shop and see the real Peruvian Culture, always try to get a discount. walk calm, you really get tired at that height.

Good Shopping. If you have time, visit the neighborhood of San Blas. We enjoyed this area more than the busy, tourist-centric Plaza de Armas. The neighborhood features "mom and pop" stores that didn't pressure us into buying their wares. The area is very picturesque and fun to just walk around. On Saturday's there is a market in the square next to the San Blas church.

Charming artsy section of Cusco. After spending about a week total in Cusco, San Blas was my favorite little section. The restaurants, shops, and boutique hotels were among the most charming, clean, and unique. The streets are postcard lovely and I felt safe walking with my friend or by myself, even at night. We were fortunate to have booked our hotel in this section, completely by chance. I recommend Casa del Campo, and Encantada Botique Spa hotels for off the beaten path, affordable small hotels.
San Blas. Great little area of Cusco. Art district. Great place to pick up some local art at great prices. Be prepared to walk hills though because this area of Cusco is up the hill.

chill, bohemian sector of Cusco. most picturesque part of Cusco! some nice lunch places and bars here too, smaller and more laid-back ones than the plaza.it's actually been the "artists quarter" since the Inca's time!
Watch the narrow streets. The streets are narrow and traveling by taxi in San Blas can at time get your heart pumping! We loved this little neighborhood with it's winding steep streets.

Nice to get lost... but watch the P00P :-(. Such a nice neighbourhood... However some people and many dogs think this is like a public toilet which really screws the experience a bit... Nevertheless, when looking where you walk this is still a grateful experience.

Great little square with best view from top of church. We went to the church to take a peak at the wood work with the artist's skull placed on the top. There is also a mini catacomb with two skeletons and a good view of cusco's tiled roofs from the top of the church.
Good place for a walk. Good place to have a walk around a people watch. There are some steep hills leading up from the bottom but it still a nice walk

Good place to people watch. Loved the little streets of San Blas, full of life, people playing random instruments and dancing around the square. Great place to sit of and just enjoy the happenings! Also plenty of nice places to grab a bite to eat and get a drink!

The place to stay in Cusco. A quaint section of Cusco just off the main plaza filled with small shops, restaurants and places to stay. Small cobblestone streets that add to the charm of this district of Cusco you cant go wrong by finding a place close to the small San Blas plaza. Has the feeling of old town with a new flair, feels like a small village above the main plaza. Best shopping in town....

San Blas. On our recent visit to Cusco, Peru, we had an opportunity to see the San Blas area. It was about a 15 minute walk from the Plaza de Armas (Square of the Warrior). It was a nice walk, but slightly uphill. The sidewalks are very narrow, but it didn't seem to be an issue as there was little vehicle traffic.San Blas is the more bohemian part of Cusco with a large variety of shops, restaurants, and colorful streets. The San Blas Church is situated on the square with the same name. The church is a simple adobe structure with a pulpit carved from a single tree trunk. It was built in the middle of the 16th century on an Incan temple site. The square was quiet on the morning we were there. And although there was a fountain, it was not running. Around the square are a number of unique artisan shops, many selling religious works, as well as the usual tourist souvenirs. Also, most of the shops were selling items of clothing made from alpaca. On our walk back down to Cusco center, we happened upon a lovely shop in an old colonial mansion. It had a central courtyard full of colorful flowers and a fountain. For any visitor to Cusco, San Blas it a must-see.

Beautiful Neighborhood. This is one of the most well conserved neighborhoods in Cusco. It's also one of the nicest, most beautiful, and most expensive. This is a great place to go to splurge on a dinner or some early evening drinks. This is /not/ the neighborhood to find economical hotels, though I'd like to think it would be possible...somewhere.

Would be really lovely if not filled with dirty hippies.. This is one of Cusco's truly iconic neighbourhoods filled with little artisan workshops, a beautiful colonial church and lots of small restaurants and bars. There is also a pretty fountain and square to sit in and soak up the vibe. The only problem is that the vibe now consists of dirty back-packing vendors who are many times high as a kite or noticeably drunk in the middle of the day. I have and always will be a bit of a tree-hugger who enjoys a drink every now and then and have back-packed through a good chunk of South America but in this case it really detracts from how beautiful the neighbourhood is. Also when I say dirty... I literally mean dirty.

Jack's Cafe best in San Blas!. I really like Jack's because they served me the best Cappucino I've had in YEARS! And it was like $3 USD. Also they serve a 'proper' American breakfast if you're in the mood for omelettes, egg sandwiches, etc. Very close to Plaza de Armas and near a little market as well. Go here!

Lovely neighborhood, right in the artisan district of Cusco. Around every corner you'll find beautiful art and textiles, as well as small little restaurants and hidden hotels...like Casa San Blas Boutique Hotel. If you're looking for a good value, and plenty of stuff to do, and just far enough away from the center of everything...this is your spot.

Salt Pans. Having never seen anything like this before, it was well worth the trip - we were there during the rainy season (and we did get stuck in the mud on the way there, but go out very quickly wih the help of all on the bus)! Lovely trip to get there!

Nice walk to see San Blas. If you have nothing else to do walk up the steep hill to San Blas.
Same shops as everywhere else. Nice square with fountain but that is about it.

Where all the hippies went!. San Blas is a very pretty area of Cusco, in what used to be a residential district above the main centre. It is characterised by small, winding streets only one car wide, almost vertical climbs, small houses and - thanks to the tourists - lots of boutique places hither and yon. It's also rather a hike up the hill, and there are fewer commercial nasties than there are further down. The place is centred around a small plaza. The church is pretty enough. There is an antiques store, a Spondylus jewellery store, a store you can have your aura read by a half Arizonan, half Peruvian 'capitalist indian', a folk art museum containing spectacular papier mache and plaster works, and a couple of the usual tourist shops. Food is also available above the plaza. There is also a market on Saturdays and Sundays (though it seems to be rather erratic) in the square. It's not cheap - if youre thinking of stocking up on souvenirs, hit the Central Market (San Pedro) down the hill. There are many travellers with earnest expressions, striped clothes, unusual facial hair and crystal jewellery...I thought they had died out years ago!

Bohemian Place. San Blas is a very nice area to visit while in Cusco. The walk from the main plaza up to San Blas is very nice, with great cobble stone streets, and amazing stone buildings. San Blas is quiet and bohemian, with lots of artists on the streets, and nice vibes.

cute little plaza. we stayed almost next to this plaza, its small and cute, a lot of people walk through there. cuscos main square is about 3 blocks down hill from here, so make sure u have confy shoes,, the streets are stone paved and they tend to get sliperry sometimes. you will also see a lot of souvenir shops make sure you dont accept the initial price when they see you are a tourist they tend to raise price ..theres is plenty restaurant close by and a couple of bars...be prepapred for the walks keep in mind cusco is located @ 3300 METERS of altitude . have fun & travel smart

Unique. Romantic , touristic , Unique area in center Cuzco . Make sure that you are wearing good NON slippery shoes . Going through involves climbing style walking on slippery shiny stone covered streets . Above the average quality souvenir stores . Do NOT waist your precious daytime hours to visit . instead save evening and/or late evening hour for this . !!! The area gets more ...''alive'' after dark . !!!

Very hilly but cute little streets, shops and little deli's/bistros. A good walk, as its very up and down, but felt safe and nice to walk around in... San Blas is the area right off the main square, behind the Cathedral. Many good little restaurants/delis/bistros with affordable (and healthy and delicious!) fruit shakes, fries, sandwiches, etc.
artists place. lovely artists habitat where you can get good coffee. If you're vegetarian head for lila's veggie place in the market.

Quaint and Quiet Neighborhood. San Blas, the artist quarter, is a labyrinth of narrow streets with great cafes, restaurants and shops to explore. It's a nice respite from the crowded and noisy central area. We stayed in San Blas and don't regret it. In fact, we spent quite a bit of time exploring the neighborhood, popping in and out of quaint cafes and shops and snapping photos at picturesque corners. The coca museum is located here, and is quite an educational and interesting experience.

San Blas market. Fun way to spend some time and money. All authentic Peruvian crafts and at reasonable prices. Indian women actually weaving the cute hats that are seen everywhere. Even a few live llamas are standing around!

The Pope liked it too. This small church has a phenomenal carved alterpiece. Although if you have been to the cathedral first, probably nothing anywhere else in any religious establishment in Cusco will particularly stand out for its wow factor. Even so, you still could not fail to be impressed by the workmanship in this particular piece.I cannot remember if it was Pope John Paul II or the current pope, back when he was a cardinal, who had visited Cusco and declared this church to be his favourite spot of all of those he visited. Tough to argue with him although his reasons were undoubtedly different from ours.Since you will undoubtedly be visiting the cathedral complex spend the extra 15 soles or so for the complete boleto religioso, which gets you into the archbishopric museum as well, and visit this small church. Do go upstairs - there is no sign telling you either to do so or that you are not allowed. The sight of the last dozen years' or so fancy robes worn, I imagine because there are no signs whatsoever, in the annual Corpus Christi procession is almost worth the price of admission in itself.You can also sneak outside onto a little balcony which gives a pretty good view of the city as well. As an added bonus the little square beside the church has a thriving artisan's market on certain days of the week.

Stay there, you won't regret it!. It's the nicest neighbourhood, just 3 blocks from the main square, with pedestrian streets!You can stay at the very well rated Pantastico Hostal and try their bakery, with plenty of yummy stuff!

great art to buy. This was a great place to buy creative, unique and well made gifts. We also enjoyed the San Blas church with the incredible pulpit which was made out of one huge piece of wood. Look for the artist's skull at the top of it. interesting.......

Nice place to ramble through. There are lots of shops and restaurants to while away an afternoon in. Some nice artisan shops, I found a shop with beautiful handmade handbags, only problem was trying to choose.
San Blas. There are endless shops and restaurants. You will walk until you are short of breath, then sit down and have a hot Mate and people watch. It is a fabulous place

get lost in the narrow streets. perfect place to get rid of your map and just get lost in the narrow, Venice-like streets. there are number of small restaurants, all serving menus for a portion of the price down the hill around Plaza de Armas. note that San Blas is located on a hill - the walk up in Cuzco at 3450m abvoe sea level can be a struggle.

Great artisany and market and food!. No: all uphill (fun when you're healthy though ;)YEEEESSSS: Great artisany, alpaca sweathers, jewelry, and a great foreign patisserie with the best brownies and cakes just up the steps of the square, on the right.

Take a walk. We walked through this area and were really impressed with the shops. We had some of the most delicious hot chocolate from a small candy shop and browsed many other local shops in the area. It is amazing to see the ancient ruins, colonial roads, and modern buildings merge together in this lovely area.
Nice day trip. It's nice to walk through these narrow streets and buy some inexpensive and very nice preuvian crafts.

Nice area, pretty touristy. The San Blas area is actually a really neat place to walk around. The streets are very narrow so that only one car can pass through and most streets cars don't even attempt to drive on. The tall white walls of the buildings hold your gaze and the many little cafes and restaurants can keep you within the few blocks for your whole trip, but might burn a hole in your wallet. This is a pretty touristy area meaning that the prices are high and there is a street vendor on every corner. It's still a good place to check out and take pictures, but look for food elsewhere if you're on a budget.

Awesome walk!. Cusco is such an amazing walking town that you cannot help but fall in love with it. The walk to San Blas with the fountains was great. We found a great lunch spot with a balcony overlooking the city. Then we made the decision to find our way to Cristo Blanco. We ended up climbing hand over hand through brush to get there.

a different dimension to cusco. this is a nice area, I went up here at night and as you go uphill and you see the back ground mountains behind you with all the street lights that go up towards it is very pretty. I wish there were more bars or at least more signs. I went to two bars both with live music from 11 pm. One of them was the 7angelitos that were having a buenavista social club band. Didnt get to stay but it was getting more crowded the later it got.
Beautiful. Beautiful neighborhood! Take comfortable walking shoes and lots of money... Dont miss the 12-angle stone!

My favorite Neighbourhood. Amazing little neighbourhood, beautiful colonial part of town on the hills of Cusco. Love walking through the little streets, walking in the little clothing stores and restaurants. Great to have a coffee there in the morning admiring the amazing views of Cusco

The highlight of Cusco!. My option of Cusco was pretty average when I arrived because of the overwhelming tourism and high prices until I discovered San Blas. This quaint area was full of cheap guesthouse accommodation and many good quality restaurants. There are many fantastic places to eat especially the San Blas market where you can get some great filling menus of the day for barely anything and some of the cheapest but best fruit salads!You cannot miss visiting San Blas if you are in Cusco!
Great to get lost up here..... Brilliant vibe, lots of interesting shops and a BRILLIANT sandwich shop called Juanitos if I recall which was an epic experience for lunch!

Beautiful Area. If you are anyway arty then you will love this part of Cusco - colourful and interesting - folk selling their wares - but not pushy or anything like it - more into discussions about different things -lovely place for a wander and lovely place to stay!! Lovely folk as well!! Loved staying in the part of the City! Highly recommend it too!
cool town. Has a bit of a hippie feel. Nice shopping. You need to visitArt by Merida. The works of Edilberto Merida. Beautiful works of art.

Great views and arty area. It's a nice walk - a bit steep (ish) but take your time, look in the alleys and shops, there are lovely sights to see on your way up here. Stop for a drink when you get to the fountain above the local square.

great area!. The San Blas area of Cusco is really nice. All those little streets (up and down) with lots of restaurants, bars, shops (artifacts, art, crafts, etc) Nice little square at the church.
It has a really nice atmosphere and that just alongside the city center.

Artsy community off the beaten path. Ditch the larger artesenal markets and get your goods here. This quaint community is tiny but packed with craft stores, antique stores and some of the best dining in Cuzco. I really wish we had stayed in this area.
Oh so nice:). The nicest little streets, perfect for spending a day chilling your way around Cusco! Certainly the place to live if you'll be staying in Cusco for a long time.
Quiet and peaceful. Like the whole area of San Blas, it's Plazoleta is nice. Quiet, peaceful and full of hippies juggling and chilling around! Good place to spend some time for yourselves;)

Cute artisan neighbourhood with places for lunch.. Cute little neighbourhood for an afternoon stroll. You most likely walk through it anyway as Cusco is relatively small. Many artisan workshops and stores. Great place for lunch is apparently Jack's bar.
Saturday Artesenal Market. Did not feel like I was getting sold to by snake oil salesman. A more relaxing place to peruse some interesting trinkets on a Saturday (believe Sat only).

Great area. Great area, restaurants, shops, galleries, crafts, music .A fantastic suburb just 10 min from the centro.Slightly uphill from centro and at the altitude it's enough to have you gasping if you don't take it easy. Great for an afternoon stroll. Galleria Merida well worth a look great pottery of the worker by now deceased potter but work goes on by widow and daughter. worth it to meet senora merida alone.

Nice neighborhood church. It's a little annoying to have to buy one's way into every church in town, but that seems to be how it is in Cusco. This one's very nice, but the plaza nearby is even nicer - great place to hang out, lovely fountain, with a bazaar on Saturdays.
Slow browse through this little holy place. Although we saw several cathederals/churches in Cusco, I really enjoyed this little church's stories, art, and displays.
Nothing better than an afternoon of aimless wandering. Beautiful old quarter. There are a mix of high-class and budget bars, cafes and restaurants. But best is just to wander.
Great Area. Built on steep hill, a wonderful area to explore, with a lovely square church and fountain at the top

Artsy neighbourhood. These tight, cobblestoned streets feature a lot of original, artsy shops. There are some true diamonds in the rough, stores that feature truly original, artistic goods. However, there are also many shops and stalls that sell the typical peruvian goods, and are not particularly original. Beware you're not overcharged for these items. Also, at night once night hits, many narrow streets do not have street lights, and can be very dangerous to navigate in the dark.

This is it!. As far as we could tell, this was the place to stay! The neighborhood is largely geared towards pedestrians, great shopping, lots of food opportunities. Just don't get swindled by the "Shaman" at the San Blas market.....beware!
great area. Worth the hike up the hill to see the colored fountains. Pachapappa restraurant is also a great find..eat in the open courtyard with a clay oven!

Avoid Sunday. Our schedule resulted in us have Sunday afternoon as free time in Cusco. We had thought to explore San Blas but found much of it closed and in hindsight we should have known better we ended up back in the Plaza de Armas where the shops were open.
Really nice. Just a short walk from the Plaza, San Blas is worth a visit. You must eat at Juanito's...the best sandwich place in Cusco!

Coolest part of Cusco. This area had the cutest stores, most helpful shopkeepers, and nicest hotels/eats. The winding, cobbled streets sometimes wound up the mountain into secret views, plazas, lounge bars, surprise chocolate or pastry shops, art galleries, and quiet neighborhoods. Late at night, some of the restaurants turned into live music venues. Artsy, creative, fascinating area.

San Blas is a place where the history is alive. . The charm of this part of the old Inca capital is captured in its steep streets and in the façades of its colonial buildings. Simple, humble but very beautiful, San Blas has become synonymous with Cusco, and any visit is sure to include it.
quaint bohemian town. is a small town with alot of hippies. Is 10 min walk from the Plaza. Nothing much to do unless you like arts..

One of the nicest waterfalls in Cusco. My favorite part of San Blas is the waterfall in the plaza. There are some lovely wooden benches that you can sit on that face the waterfall. I don' t think that people are really that genuine that sit around making jewelry and slowly become dirtier and stinker. It's an experience that you could do or not do. There are more enjoyable and more beautiful places in Cusco, don't miss out on other adventures.
Dining and art. We stayed fairly close to San Blas and enjoyed the dining and art that is in this area. There is also interesting buildings to observe and narrow alleyways to explore
Good food and shopping. This area has lots of good shops and resturants and the main plaza has a pretty fountain that the locals performed in each night

Walking through alleys. Have a walk from the alley on the right hand-side watching the Cathedral from the Plaza and you'll go through a very tiny alley where you'll see the 12 angle's stone and then go up through a steep alley with stairs and you'll reach San Blas neighbourough, where you can get lost in the small alleys and exploring the place. At night there's a very nice place called Los 7 angelitos, where you can get food, beer and live music and don't miss out the other one " Km 0 ", where you'll get the same things.
Lovely street. The best street in Cusco City. Many shops, hotels,restaurants, museums and historical places. Just take your time as it goes uphill.

best place to shop. Check out the small shops ofering fair trade handicrafts. Their products are actualy made by hand and are much nicer than the tourist junk you see everywhere. There are vendors in the square that you can bargain with, and some Peruvian hippies selling funky jewelry.

Artisan area. The cathedral was a surprise inside, since it is so simple on the outside, The many shops around the square are great to visit. As the morning went on, more and more people set up tables in the square to sell their crafts.
Just unique !. Beautiful area, full of life, restaurants, that unique Cusco look and very close to the main Plaza de Armas.

Cute Area. San Blas is a nice little walk about with varying little things to see. I is supposed to be an artisanal area and there is a night market which I found on Friday and Saturday nights. I found it fun to find all of the super-steep roads/walkways and stairs.
Saturday market. Try to be there on Saturday morning to visit the artesanal market.Very lively with sellers of knitwear, paintings, music instruments
Great neighborhood to wander about. But it is steep! Not something to tackle upon arrival in Cusco is you're not prepared for altitude sickness.
Get lost!. Great area that is very chill during the day and has great views. Lots of neat little narrow streets to explore aimlessly. Stop and have a beer outside looking over Cusco!

Great area less the bussle of Plaza De Armas. San Blas is a great area to wander through the cobble stone streets. It is a little steep walking up to get there but the views are worth it. I did this yesterday and would consider walking there near sunset to get the night views. There is a little church up in the plaza with many artisan shops around and with lots of restaurants and cafes to choose from.Also saw a few Yoga places if you are a yoga fanatic. Enjoyed this area much more than down the main touristy square.

THE area to stay in. We got lucky and ended up in a Hostal in San Blas. This is the area to be in. It is just a short walk from the main square and all the shopping you will ever need to do. Great restaurants that aren't quite as crowded as the other side of the square which we avoided, just too many people.

A real local feel and great art!. I went in the evening when the locals were out enjoying a costumed show for the children! The energy was exuberant! The plaza is small, but lined with jewelry and textiles from local artisans. Most was of much better quality and skill than can be found at the Inca Market. Don't miss visiting the small historic church or the many art galleries. My personal favorite was the small museum set up by the Mendívil family known for their long-neck sculptures. It will seem a bit scary at first walking through a small passageway, but it opens up to a small courtyard where the family lives and works. There you can view some of the art being made as well as a room full of long-neck sculptures made by their family.

Interesting to explore. A short, but steep, walk up from the Plaza de Armas, this little neighborhood was colorful and surprising with its artisans working in the plaza outdoors. It was worth a few hours during an afternoon stroll. The prices for goods were reasonable there, too.

Prepare to go UP, UP, UP. San Blas area of Cusco is neat....but be prepared to climb stairs....that along with the altitude...you'll be huffing and puffing. Just wander around the narrow streets and admire the views. The doors of the houses are beautiful, often with carved animals or symbols above them. Sneak a peek into some of the courtyards.... you can actually climb all the way up to the Christ Redeemer statue.....
very bohemian - worth to go there!. magnificant artists, marvellous typical houses, very nice Plaza with little shops and restaurants. Very nice galleries! art is not very expensive there.
cool neighborhood. its got its own vibe but is still walking distance to the center square. lots of great restaurants and good area to check out in cusco

Great for wandering and eating and the views. My favorite thing about San Blas is the winding cobble stone streets and the white wash walls perched on top of the old Inca stonework. You could take a map, but it's better just to start wandering and let yourself be surprised. Beautiful purple Bougainvillea flow over some of the walls. There are some shops and restaurants, especially near the Plazoleta San Blas but apart from that it's quiet and quaint. So take a left at Carmen Alto, and then a right at Siete Angelitos, then take a turn down Siete Diablos and keep wandering. You can always walk down the hill to get to the plaza or up to get to the highway, Cristo Blanco and Sacsayhuaman ruins. Aside from climbing all the way up to the road San Blas offers some of the best views over the Cusco valley. As for the plazoleta, it's great place to sit in the sun and read a book. You can people watch too, but it's a lot calmer than the Plaza de Armas. Hippies and street artists regularly gather to practice and mingle in the Plazoleta. There's little church and a small artisan market on the weekends and some great little shops that surround the plaza. Do you do yoga? Visit Cusco Yoga Inbound for a 1.5 hr class in the morning or the evening. Visit the Frogs or 7 Angelitos bar for live music. The Meeting Place is a nice spot for coffees and light lunch. Proceeds go to a good cause. El Buen Pastor is the best for a pastry. If the San Pedro market is too overwhelming for you, try the San Blas market. Just climb up the steps above the purple wall and fountain and hang a right and then another right once you hit the end of the alley. The offerings are simpler but prices may be better. Stop in for a pizza dinner at the cozy Sumaq restaurant on 7 Angelitos. The competitor across the street is delicious too! Then there Prasada I and II and El Encuentro for vegetarians and Jack's for good homey food. Te quiero mucho, San Blas.
Excellent shopping!. Loads of beautiful hand-crafted goods. Be ready for a little prodding from the vendors. :o)

Charming. This neighborhood has very steep and narrow alleyways, with quaint little shops and restaurants. It has an artsy, festive atmosphere. At San Cristobal Church, there are beautiful views of Cusco below and the mountains beyond. We really enjoyed spending time in San Blas.
Nice part of town. This is a great part of Cusco. I looks down on the city and at night it was beautiful.

Interesting Area--Hard Walking. Somewhat away from the tourist hordes, this is a very interesting part of Cusco. If you continue walking up behind the church, you get good views and explore interesting alleyways, etc.There are many very good and inexpensive restaurants in the area. To name two of the favorites located on Calle Choquechaca--Jacks' Cafe (usually crowded) and Quinta Eulalia (wonderful Peruvian/Andean food). My favorite is Pacha Papa, opposite the Church of San Blas. It has a delightful interior courtyard to eat in and the food is exceedingly good and Peruvian. I would highly recommend "salterito"--an appetizer of lima beans, cheese, corn, peas, onions and tomatoes.No real dislikes. But for some the steep walk up to San Blas from Plaza de Armas would be a major slog. If walking is not your thing, you can take a taxi up to the Church and walk down.

Our hostal was here. We stayed at Amaru I on the prettiest street in San Blas...home of the famous 12 angled stone. It was a delight to walk to and from our various activities each day along these beautiful, narrow streets. They are filled with artisans selling their crafts.

Great views. Great views. Only walk up there when you are acclimatized to the altitude and be prepared to be hassled non-stop by people selling paintings and asking for donations. I did, however, buy a painting and the art student was very kind to then show me around and explain things about the buildings.

Very pretty little spot with great atmosphere.. We went to San Blas to see the square, the church, and the fountains. At the very top of the square, they have great weaving and alpaca scarves for very reasonable prices. This is a pretty little spot and we enjoyed the walk from Rumi Punku (only a five-minute walk to San Blas.
Small market place. Cute stop if you are wandering by, but not worth going out of your way for. Seems to be the same items being sold in every other shop.
Nice!. Don't miss walking up to this area! Great view at the top. Lots of good artists shops. Some bars.

Lovely small plaza, waterfall and church. This was a very lovely small plaza. We came from Cusco and approached through some small streets. The plaza is a bit below the main street level and is surrounded by small shops and St Blas church.

Beautiful plaza!. San Blas area has nice cobbled streets and traditional houses. The small plaza of San Blas is really cute and has an open market with interesting things to see and buy. Also from the top of the plaza (up the stairs) you can enjoy beautiful views. Nice and cheap cafes and light lunch in the area too!
It is just fine. We stayed in an apartment in San Blas and while we liked living there, I don't see any reason for tourists to come. There are some shops and a church but nothing special.
charming. My hotel was in san Blas and it's so charming.... The narrow streets are kind of romantic!
Unique in the world. This neighborhood is unique, walking at night, in those streets, very romantic, very special.

Cultural place. My whole family enjoy a free dance performance for free in this petite square , good place to purchase handycrafts of course before buying any thing ask for a reduction on the price in every thing you want to buy from the street sellers
An area to explore.. Cusco is a great city, yet small enough to walk to most places/sights without any problems. San Blas is an area you souldn't miss.

Nice place to stay. We stayed in a hotel in this area and shopped as well. The choices are limited but we did find some great deals. It is a little away from the bustle of center of Cusco but by no means quiet. You will find it fun.
Place of artists. Nice narrow streets and square. There are many locals selling paintings and jewellery.

A little out of the way square with a lot going on at it. A little out of the way square with a lot going on at it. We stayed near here or we might not have gone to this site. But there was always a lot going on at it. If you are not staying up in the hills of the San Blas district, as we did, you might want to come here anyway to get a feel for the hilly nature of the area with the tight streets. You will not wonder why you do not see locals smoking if you hike up to this square. when you h

Great place to stay. We stayed at the Pension Alemana and the area is the neighborhood to stay at. We walked during daytime and every night (even at late hours), we always felt safe. The area has a bohemian mood to it, the streets are stone paved, you find multiple handcraft shops, painting stores, coca store (that sells coca cookies and brownies) and several bars and restaurants. Just be prepared for a walk...as it is hilly.
Trinkets line the way.... Nice view from the top, but you'll have to fight the barrage of trinket sellers and choch along the way... Many more interesting sights to see without the uphill walk.
Not much oging on!. We walked over to San Bas twice to see what it had to offer. Both time the plaza was devoid of merchants and shoppers!

Such a cool vibe to this neighborhood!. We stayed in San Blas before and after our Inca Trail hike. You can walk everywhere. There are tons of restaurants, shops, bars, and art galleries. We traveled all around Cusco on our visit, but loved loved loved San Blas and will be staying there again on my next visit!!

Close, but not too close. We stayed at Pension Alamenia and really enjoyed it. We were a 5 min walk from the main square and had a scenic view of Cuzco and surrounding mountains.
Also San Blas has good restaurants and unique shops.

Fantastic old ruin. An ingenious attempt by the Incas to manufacture Micro climates for the use of Agricuture, also a visit to the Desecrated Inca cemetry was facinating, to get the most out of this, a guide is a must.

Walk through this district taking your time. There are so many interesting places and art shops. You have to spend time here, browse through the narrow streets and go into the little courtyards and shops, you will find very nice Peruvian crafts here. Be aware that many women and children will approach you, with a lama by their side, asking you to take a photograph. The catch is that they expect you to pay up to 5 soles for each photo, so choose your 'models' with care.

Excellent choice of small restaurants.. Don't pay high prices in Cuzco in 'recommended' restaurants, not worth the money. Instead eat and drink in a variety of small restaurant/cafes by the San Blas area: you can have a 2 course menu for about 8-12 new Soles.

Bohemian part of Cusco. Cusco could be the tourist trap that you would want to avoid but we have to say that it has too much charm and too much character to call it a tourist trap. We think you'll find that its just more than a stop over to Machu Picchu. Check out the Bohemian section of the Cusco. There you can find a lot of great restaurants, cafes, and museums that have a little different "flavor" than the shops near the center. You'll see what we are talking about when you get there.

Visit to San Blas. We walked uphill (many tourist shops along the way) to visit this small colonial church with good views from the tower. We had limited time and with hindsight would have given the San Blas area a miss.
Great for a Walk. I would recommend taking a walk up San Blas while you are in Cuzco- it is a beautiful part of town! Just watch out for the street vendors!
Cozy area. We stay here at Nawin Cusco Eco Apts. The host were great & very helpful.

Interesting neighborhood. Cuzco is a terrific town if you take time there. We were there three nights and had two full days to explore. San Blas is a charming neighborhood but be warned that if you walk, it is a bit of climb up to it. Some artisan stalls, galleries, but we enjoyed just street walking and people watching.

One of the best places in Cuzco. All of Cuzco is wonderful.... San Blas is a must. It is not as busy as Plaza de Armas which makes it nice. Also, the street vendors are less in your face and the surrounding stores are more friendly, very Mom and Pop.
I love it. So much that i bought a house here... any questions dont be shy.. its my home.

smaller than expected. The hype of San Blas is more than the actual experience. There was very little to see. However, the walk there is nice on the cobblestone streets. It takes about 10 minutes from the Plaza de Armas. There are some shops along the way selling expensive artsy items. The day we went there was a craft show in the Plaza. Mostly the same touristy things they sell in the center of Cusco. A so-called "shaman" tried to hustle me by reading my aura and telling me that I needed to buy a $220 USD pendant from him to cure what ailed me. I declined. The entire trip to San Blas took about an hour, then we were bored and left.
The artists shops. Take your time & explore. There are so many individual artists shops, everything from jewelry to paintings to clothing. Everyone was very friendly.

An older part of Cusco. This part of Cusco is a bit of a hike from the Plaza de Armas in Cusco, especially at the altitude of 11,00o ft., but it is worth it. There is a beautiful church in the Plaza, a really cool fountain and a ton of artisans selling all kinds of Jewelry, sweaters, food and (anything else that you may want to relax). There are a lot of good restaurants and bars that have live music. The musicians in Peru are really good and they love their 80s and 90s rock mixed with local Peruvian favorites. Great for a stop during your day or dinner at night. Pizza, Indian Cuisine and Peruvian food, of course. Don't forget to try a Pisco Sour!

Interesting area of old Cusco - narrow steep streets. This is an interesting place to just walk up and down the streets. Some are very steep. Lots of small stores selling art and other crafts. Also lots of restaurants. Also the location of the 12 sided stone which is interesting if you like the Inca architecture.

Don't mind the climb. It's a bit of a puff getting up the hills and staircases that link San Blas together but well worth it to enjoy a traditional and unspoilt Cusco neighbourhood. I wonder how they move furniture in and out of so many house that don´t have road access. There are great eateries and Korma Sutra Indian restaurant is a gem!

Cool trendy area with better products for sale than the plaza. This area is great for grabbing a bargin and some beautiful clothing, you have to hunt it out though. Only problem is that it is at the top of a hill. Ensure you are acclimatised before venturing out this far, even small hills can take the wind out of you sail at this alititude if youre not used to it.

Trendy Cusco. I've never stayed in San Blas during my visits to Cusco, but I've walked the streets and just love this area. It's the trendy area of Cusco, offering higher end products to adventurer and tourists. Its very quaint and quiet.
Don't skip this place!. Enjoy Cuzco by your own feets.. just wallk and breath!

San Blas neighborhood - Cusco. Our hotel was in this part of Cusco and we passed through the Plaza San Blas a few times each day. There was almost always something going on in the plaza. People set up stalls and sold art and handwork. There was a performance by Andean dancers one night. There was usually some music. There are a few good restaurants and some art galleries and studios. Very enjoyable.

Important Artisian Community. You will find not only the most famous artists here but it is also peaceful, lovely with the water feature and also to see school children. It is a great place to buy authentic mirrors. I recommend Mendivil two locations very special.

Tourist Cental. San Blas is a great neighborhood with lots of artisan shops, restaurants, bars, hotels/hostels, and general places catering to tourists. It will not give you much of an "authentic" Peruvian feel, but it's a great place to eat, shop around, and meet other tourists.

Lovely old streets. This is a great part of Cuzco. You feel like you have stepped back in time walking around here. There are lots of streets with stairs, so it keeps you in good shape and you get to see some nice vistas of Cuzco from the higher parts. It is a very nice way to spend a couple of hours.
Handcrafts market. San blas hosts a nice handcrafts market on saturdays at the plaza and many art galleries surrounding it. The views from Cusco are beautiful.
Go here!!. This is a really cool area of Cuzco. I highly recommend walking around the neighborhood!

Wish there were more open options. I thought that San Blas would have more restaurants, shops, bars, etc. Maybe I didn't hit the right streets or have the magic password, but it was hard to find any real activity after the merchants on the square closed down. Fountain, Church and Square were good.

Lovely area of Cusco. My favourite part of Cusco this area is behind the main cathedral in Plaza de Armas. Full of small cobbled streets and alleyways. Boutique hotels, coffee shops, small independent shops and some lovely restaurants.
San Blas!. One of the most beautiful places to wander around.The little house with pink or blue doors, it is great.Being in San Blas at dawn is one of the most beautiful memories I have.

Fun artist neighborhood. This neighborhood is a bit of a climb from the Plaza, but well worth a visit. Find lots of cute little restaurants and hotels here, as well small art exhibitions and shops. Look for the house of Hilario Mendivil whose work is characterized by the long necks, and for the house of the local ceramic artist (how I wish I had written down his name) whose work is known for its big hands and feet, symbolizing the hard labor of the campesinos. A lot of hidden gems in this neighborhood, and pleasant to stroll around in.

Better take a taxi and walk back down to the Plaza. San Blas is a beautiful part of town. It's about 15 - 20 minutes walk from San Blas to Plaza de armas. The best way to visit this place is to take a taxi from Plaza de Armas (very cheap) and then walk back down. I think it's not more than 5 soles. usually the driver will stop at the church and you can walk around the area. There are some nice souvenir shops around also.

Favorite Part of Town. I really liked this area of Cusco but if your going up there prepare to walk uphill (or take a taxi if your lazy). Check out The Meeting Place if your homesick for some American food.

Great place to unwind and see a "non-touristy" Cusco. We loved San Blas! Sit on a bench and listen to the didgeridoo player near the fountain. Smell the incense, wander through the art shops and listen to live music in one of the many artsy bars. Walk through the cobblestone streets and stop in for some brick oven pizza. San Blas is much more relaxed that Plaza de Armas. No vendors, few tourists....just a cool spot to watch the sun set.
The best part of Cusco to stay. Handy to everything with an unspoilt character. I stayed at Casa de mama de cusco - good value

Beautiful square in Cusco. This beautiful square is located in San Blas the Bohemian artistic neighborhood of Cusco. Here you can find several good artisan shops, restaurants and bars with live music. The square also provides great views of the city.
nice neighborhood, more hippies than downtown. The traditional artists's barrio in Cusco. Look for the sculptor's home off the plaza (creates the famous long-neck pieces).

The Bohemian Cusco. This part of Cusco is something looked over by visitors with little time in Cusco. It takes some effort to get there but once there you can enjoy some of the most beautiful streets and squares in Cusco. On top of this it has also great views on the surroundings.

artistic heart. The artisans of san blas were one of the reasons I visited cusco a second time. The san blas plaza is surrounded by wood workers and artists practicing techniques dating back to the early colonial times when the cusco school of art was most famous. On the weekend the artisans market is a must see.
Cobblestone streets. Lots of things to see, art shops, intersting hotels good restuarants. Easy to spend a whole day exploring
lovely area. safe. lovely sqare with shops bars and restaurants. close to hostel.

Worth the climb to this picturesque part of Cusco with great views over the city. A picturesque locale with a church and square which with its white walled houses and blue painted doors and windows has a real Mediterranean feel. Lots of shops down alleys off the mmain street which is quite steep and demands a slower pace in the rarified air. Plenty of local colour and atmosphere.
San Blas. If I could choose to live in Cusco I would definitive would live in this neighborhood.
San Blas. Nice quiet area with artisan shops and pleasant buildings

Worth the hike uphill. Walk around this bohemian neighborhood and slip into the Meeting Place Cafe on Plazoleta San Blas. As you walk up towards the mountains there are great views of Cuzco city center.

Bohemian, quaint, makes you linger. Great area to stay while in Cuzco. It's full of bars, cafés, restaurants and hostals to keep you entertained and chilled out for days. I wouldn't stay anywhere else in Cuzco.

Nice area. This section of Cusco, adjacent to the Plaza de Arrmas has many little restaurants, shops and hotels. The competition keeps the prices down and the value up. Plenty of places to enjoy a drink.

hostels and shopping. The tight streets and winding roads were a challenge. Most of what we saw in San Blas were hostels and shopping opportunities. We did happen upon some sort of play happening in front of the fountain in the main plaza.

Quaint and well worth a visit. Pleasant, convenient area with shops, restaurants and other attractions.A steep walk up from town but worth it. We sat in the square after lunch which was most pleasant. A slight 'hippy' air about it maybe ( reminiscent of my youth in the 60s!!). We tried to get into the church but two chaps sitting on the steps barred the way and wanted money. We retreated, sensing a scam attempt.

Great location for a stay in Cusco. Great location, lots of restaurants and bars but has that quiet village feel. Lost count of the number of corner shops and laundry places so great for an extended stay.

Must See. You have to take a few hours and walk around San Blas. I enjoyed the old narrow streets and found many different things for sale in and around the square. I was told not to walk around there at night by myself but that applies for many places.

Exceptional artists including two of Cusco's most famous sculptors. This precious plaza with the cathedral, children, fountains, great restaurants and the most beautiful artisian work I have seen. Olave and Mendivil are famous and you can just stand there wathcing them work and truly feel inspired.This is a bohemian district of San Blas, where you will enjoy popular artists who are dedicated to weaving, sculpting, and molding wonderful works of art.I plan to study spanish in a school called The Amauta which is located in this devine district.
beautiful place. i liked the sotres with a lot of souvenirs, the restaurantes, the people
Not all that. If you are looking to score some sweet deals San Blas is not the place for you. Things were much cheaper in the Cusco markets.
very well located!. This charming street is the best street to stay overnight! Close to everything : the center, good restaurants, ...
Great value, great location. Other than a barking dog and lots of street noise, we loved this place. Free internet in the lobby too.

Ahhh, San Blas. OK I'm probably looking at this through rose-tinted spectacles, but I love Cusco and San Blas is where I lived for a few months (my mate stayed there for 2 years!) You're living amongst/with Peruvians, there's a great view across the city, it really is a lovely little neighbourhood. If you can, visit for the fiesta of los trembeladors, it's brilliant.
